description: The issues on certiorari are whether a witness  was properly qualified as an expert in the field of forensic interviewing, and whether the witness' testimony was harmless.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        William R.
          Douglas, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT THE
COURT APPEALS

Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26577
  Heard September 16, 2008 - Filed January
12, 2009

AFFIRMED IN RESULT; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Deputy
          Chief Appellate Defender for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David
          Spencer, all of Columbia, and Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

___________
JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  We granted certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in State
    v. Douglas, 367 S.C. 498, 626 S.E.2d 59 (2006).Â  We affirm, in result, and
  reverse in part.Â  
FACTS
Petitioner,
  William R. Douglas, was convicted of committing a lewd act on a minor.Â  The
  Victim, who was 10 years old at the time of trial, testified she was molested
  by Douglas when she was 7 years old.Â  When the Victim told her Grandmother about
  the abuse one year later, she was taken to see Gwen Herod, the Sumter County
  Victimâ€™s Assistance Officer.Â  
Herod
  testified at trial that she conducts â€œforensic interviewsâ€ with child victims
  and follows the children through the court system.Â  Douglas objected to her
  qualification as an expert, contending there is no such field of expertise.Â  Douglas also asserted Herodâ€™s testimony improperly bolstered Victimâ€™s testimony and was
  unduly prejudicial.Â  The court qualified Herod as an expert, finding her testimony
  relevant and admissible. Â 
Herod
  testified before the jury that she does â€œforensic interviewingâ€ using the RATAC
  method.[1]Â 
  Herod testified that she had testified in court several times before.Â  Although
  she did not have a college degree, she had attended a 40-hour training course
  on forensic interviewing, and had completed two weeks of training classes.Â  She
  had been a victimâ€™s advocate for the solicitorâ€™s office for eleven years, and
  had interviewed hundreds of victims.Â  According to Herod, the RATAC method is
  used nationwide and is known as forensic interviewing of children.Â  
Herod
  testified before the jury about the RATAC method, stating:

  During the rapport stage, Iâ€™m building a rapport with this child,
    we are talking about school or things that she enjoys, Iâ€™m introducing myself
    to her, telling her what my role is and going over the rules of the interview,
    we talk a lot about telling the truth and telling a lie and we make an
    agreement with each other that I will tell her the truth and that she will tell
    me the truth, if we get past that, if the child agrees to do that, we go on to
    name, I find out about their family . . . 

Herod then
  testified she utilized the RATAC method with Victim in this case, and that as a
  result, she received information which led her to conclude a follow up was
  necessary, and that the victim needed to go to the Durant Center for a medical
  evaluation.Â  
The
  Court of Appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s qualification of Herod as an expert
  in the field of forensic interviewing.Â  The Court of Appeals further found
  that, in any event, Herodâ€™s testimony was harmless and did not improperly
  bolster Victimâ€™s testimony.
ISSUE
Did the
  Court of Appeals err in affirming the qualification of Herod as an expert in
  the field of forensic interviewing, and in affirming admission of her
  testimony?
DISCUSSION
The
  Court of Appeals held â€œthe trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding
  Herod had â€˜acquired by study or practical experience such knowledge of the
  subject matter of [her] testimony as would enable [her] to give guidance and
  assistance to the jury in resolving a factual issue which is beyond the scope
  of the juryâ€™s good judgment and common knowledge.â€™â€Â  Douglas, 367 S.C.
  at 519, 626 S.E.2d at 70.Â  (Internal citation omitted).Â  The Court of Appeals
  also found the trial court had sufficient evidence that forensic interviewing
  was a recognized field, and that, in any event, any error was harmless.Â  Under
  the facts presented here, we find it was unnecessary for Herod to be qualified
  as an expert.Â  
Pursuant
  to Rule 601, SCRE, every person is competent to be a witness unless otherwise
  provided by statute or the rules.Â  Rule 602, SCRE, prohibits a witness from
  testifying to matters unless evidence is introduced sufficient to demonstrate
  the witness has personal knowledge.Â  Rule 602 is subject to the provisions of
  Rule 703, SCRE, which provides:

  The facts or data in the particular case upon which an expert
    bases an opinion or inference may be those perceived by or made known to the
    expert at or before the hearing. If of a type reasonably relied upon by experts
    in the particular field in forming opinions or inferences upon the subject, the
    facts or data need not be admissible in evidence.

Lay
  witnesses are permitted to offer testimony in the form of opinions or
  inferences if the opinions or inferences are rationally based on the witnessâ€™
  perception, and will aid the jury in understanding testimony, and do not
  require special knowledge.Â  Rule 701, SCRE; State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 469 S.E.2d 49 (1996). Â 
Here, Herod
  testified she had been employed as the Sumter County victimâ€™s assistance
  officer since 1998.Â  Although she did not have a college degree, she had
  attended a 40-hour training course on forensic interviewing, and had completed
  two weeks of training classes.Â  She had interviewed hundreds of victims and had
  testified in court several times before.Â  Herod testified she had been back for
  follow up courses and advanced courses and that there was a monthly national
  newsletter in order to enable her to keep up with things going on nationwide
  regarding the forensic interviewing process.Â  
Herod
  also testified as to her utilization of the R-A-T-A-C method to establish a
  rapport with child victims, and testified as to her interview with the victim
  in this case.Â  Ultimately, Herod testified that based on the interview, it was
  her opinion the victim needed to go to the Durant Center for a medical exam.Â Â Â  
We find
  the testimony given by Herod in the present case simply was not required to be
  presented by an expert witness.[2]Â 
  Herod testified only as to her personal observations and experiences, and her
  interview with the Victim in this case.Â  Accordingly, we find it was
  unnecessary for the trial court to have qualified her as an expert.Â  However, although
  Herod did not need to be so qualified in this case, we nonetheless affirm the
  result reached by the Court of Appeals, because Douglas suffered no prejudice either
  as a result of Herodâ€™s testimony or by her qualification as an expert.Â  
Douglas contends, in part, that Herodâ€™s testimony was unduly prejudicial inasmuch as the
  jury was likely to give her testimony undue weight simply because of her
  qualification as an expert.Â  Such a contention is untenable.Â  The same tests
  which are commonly applied in the evaluation of ordinary evidence are to be
  used in judging the weight and sufficiency of expert testimony.Â  Anderson v. Campbell Tile Co., 202 S.C. 54, 24 S.E.2d 104 (1943). Â As with
  any witness, the jury is free to accept or reject the testimony of an expert
  witness.Â  State v. Milian-Hernandez, 287 S.C. 183, 186, 336 S.E.2d 476,
  478 (1985).Â  The fact that Herod was qualified as an expert did not require the
  jury to accord her testimony any greater weight than that given to any other
  witness.Â Â  Â Â Â 
Douglas further asserts that Herodâ€™s testimony could have been construed by the jury as
  vouching for Victimâ€™s veracity, such that it should have been excluded under
  Rule 403, SCRE, because its prejudicial impact outweighed its probative value.Â 
  We disagree.Â  Initially, we note that the Court of Appeals concluded that
  â€œ[t]he only reasonable inference the jury could have drawn from Herodâ€™s
  testimony is that she believed the victim told the truth about being sexually
  assaulted.â€Â  367 S.C. at 520, 626 S.E.2d at 71.Â  This was error.Â Â  Herod never
  stated she believed Victim; she did not even state the Victim in this case
  agreed to tell her the truth, and she gave no indication concerning Victimâ€™s
  veracity.Â  Herod testified only that, in conducting forensic interviews and
  building a rapport with a child, they talk about things.Â  She stated, â€œIâ€™m
  introducing myself to her, telling her what my role is and going over the rules
  of the interview, we talk a lot about telling the truth and telling a lie and
  we make an agreement with each other that I will tell her the truth and that
  she will tell me the truth, if we get past that, if the child agrees to do
  that, we go on.â€Â  There is no evidence whatsoever that Herod believed the
  Victim to be telling the truth.Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that
  the only reasonable inference is that Herod believed Victim was telling the
  truth is reversed. 
Moreover, the only opinion given by Herod was that she
  concluded Victim needed a medical exam. Â A pediatric nurse practitioner thereafter
  examined Victim and determined she had vaginal tearing and scarring consistent
  with past penetration. Â In light of this evidence, there is no conceivable
  prejudice to Douglas from Herodâ€™s testimony.Â  Accord State v.
    Shumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) (probative value of the rape
  trauma evidence outweighed prejudicial effect).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Given
  the nature of Herodâ€™s testimony, which was based upon her own personal
  observations and discussions with child victims, we find it was unnecessary to
  qualify her as an expert in this case.Â Â  Herod testified to the manner in which
  she conducts interviews, and testified as to her recommendation upon
  interviewing the Victim in this case.Â  This testimony simply did not need to be
  in the form of expert testimony.Â  Accordingly, to the extent the Court of
  Appeals upheld the qualification of Herod as an expert in this case, its
  opinion is reversed.Â  However, because Herodâ€™s testimony did not vouch for the
  veracity of the Victim, and was not prejudicial to Douglas, we affirm the
  result reached by the Court of Appeals.Â  
REVERSED IN PART; AFFIRMED IN RESULT.
Â TOAL, C.J., BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J.,
dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority
  that the Court of Appeals erred in upholding the qualification of Herod.Â 
  However, because I find that Herodâ€™s testimony was prejudicial to the
  defendant, I respectfully dissent, and would remand for a new trial.
In my opinion, it
  was not only unnecessary but improper for the circuit court to qualify Herod as
  an expert witness.Â  This Courtâ€™s jurisprudence and Rule 702 of the South
  Carolina Rules of Evidence emphasize the role of the trial court as the
  gatekeeper in determining, among other things, whether the expertâ€™s testimony
  consists of scientific, technical, or specialized knowledge that will assist
  the trier of fact. Fields v. J. Haynes Water Builders, Inc., 376 S.C.
  545, 658 S.E.2d 80 (2008); Rule 702, SCRE.Â  In my opinion, while much of
  Herodâ€™s factual testimony was admissible, it did not assist the jury in
  assessing matters beyond its common knowledge and was therefore not proper
  expert testimony.Â  
Herodâ€™s
  testimony went to an ultimate issue for the jury: the victimâ€™s credibility.Â 
  Herod testified that in applying the RATAC method, she and the victim â€œtalk a
  lot about telling the truth and telling a lie and we make an agreement with
  each other that I will tell her the truth and that she will tell me the truthâ€
  and â€œif the child agrees to do thatâ€ Herod continues the interview.Â  Herod
  testified that after concluding the interview, she determined â€œthat [the
  victim] needed to go to the Durant Center for a medical exam . . . .â€Â  I agree
  with the Court of Appeals that the only reasonable conclusion to be drawn from
  Herodâ€™s testimony is that, based upon her training, she believed that the
  victim was being truthful.Â  Juries do not require the assistance of human
  â€œtruth detectorsâ€ in assessing the credibility of testimony.
I cannot agree with
  the majority that qualifying Herod as an expert was harmless.Â  As in many CSC
  cases, this case turned primarily on the veracity of the victim.Â  In the
  instant case, while physical evidence indicated that the victim had been
  abused, no physical evidence other than the testimony of the victim connected
  Petitioner to the crime.Â  Notwithstanding that expert testimony is to be
  assessed utilizing the same tests of credibility applied to that of non-expert
  witnesses, qualification as an expert clothes the witness with an air of
  authority that does not attach to â€œordinaryâ€ witnesses.Â  In his closing
  argument, counsel for the State noted â€œwhat this comes down to is believability
  and credibilityâ€ and contrasted his â€œexpertâ€ witnesses with witnesses presented
  by the defense.[3]Â 
  Given the importance of credibility in this case, Herodâ€™s testimony in this
  regard was not harmless. See State v. Ellis, 345 S.C. 175, 178,
  547 S.E.2d 490, 492 (2001) (â€œAn officerâ€™s improper opinion which goes to the
  heart of the case is not harmless.â€). 
For
the reasons given above, I respectfully dissent.


[1]Â  Herod testified R-A-T-A-C was an acronym for Rapport;
Anatomy; Touch; Abuse Scenario; Closure.Â  
[2] Â We are not unmindful that numerous states in
  recent years have upheld the qualification of expert witnesses in the field of
  forensic interviewing.Â  See, e.g., Kilby v. Commonwealth, 663
  S.E.2d 540 (Va. 2008); Golden v. State, 984 So.2d 1026 (Miss. App.
  2008); Lattimer v. State, 2006 WL 1073190 (Miss. Ct. App. 2006), cert.
    denied 951 So.2d 563 (Miss. 2007); Mooneyham v. Mississippi, 915 So.
  2d 1102 (Miss. Ct. App. 2005); State v. Speers, 98 P.3d 560, 566
  (Ariz.Ct.App.2004); In re A.H., 578 S.E.2d 247 (Ga. Ct. App. 2003); State
    v. Thompson, 799 A.2d 1126 (Conn. App. 2002); Siharath v. State, 246
  Ga.App. 736, 737-738, 541 S.E.2d 71 (Ga. App. 2000) (no abuse of discretion in
  court qualifying witness as an expert in forensic evaluation); Louisiana v.
    Hilton, 764 So. 2d 1027 (La. Ct. App. 2000).Â  Under Rule 702, SCRE, â€œ[i]f
  scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of
  fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness
  qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education,
  may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€Â  See Baggerly
    v. CSX Transport, Inc., 370 S.C. 362, 635 S.E.2d 97 (2006).Â  Although there
  may be a case in which qualification of an expert in this field is proper, we
find no such necessity in the present case.Â  
[3] In his closing argument, counsel for the State argued: â€œwhat this comes down to
  is believability and credibility.Â  Whatâ€™s believable, the testimony of that
  little girl and what she told you here in this courtroom, followed up with an
  expert in interviewing and followed up with an expert in medical examination
  and confirmed by her grandmother.Â  Thatâ€™s the evidence, not mom who gets on the
  stand who doesnâ€™t ever say anything about this Terry guy and the fact that she
  was gone to church and other places or James Wandtke, the best friend who[â€™s]
here to help my buddy out . . . .â€

description: The court affirmed an order dismissing this suit citing the doctrine of collateral estoppel.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Ross Marine,
          LLC, Arthur R. Swygert, Jr., Kathy Speights and Swygert Shipyards, Inc., Appellants,
        v.
        Query, Sautter,
          & Gliserman, LLC, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
  Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Special Circuit
Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26578
  Heard November 6, 2008 - Filed January 12,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        William
          A. Scott, of Pedersen & Scott, of Charleston, for Appellants.
        Michael
          W. Sautter, of Query, Sautter, Gliserman & Price, of Charleston, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  


\JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  This is an appeal from an order finding no evidence of a
  conflict of interest.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR, on the ground
  relitigation of the alleged conflict is barred by the doctrine of collateral
  estoppel.Â  See Zurcher v. Belton, 379 S.C. 132, 666 S.E.2d 264
  (2008).
FACTS
Attorney
  Query has represented David Browder since approximately 1984.Â  In 1993, Browder
  went to work for appellant Ross Marine.[1]Â 
  Browder recommended attorney Query to Ross Marine, and over the next seven
  years Query and attorney Gliserman represented Ross Marine in several legal
  matters.Â  Browder, who was employed by Ross Marine as managing sales representative,
  was the primary contact between Ross Marine and the attorneys regarding these
  legal matters: most of the suits were collection actions brought by Ross
  Marine, although Query defended Ross Marine in a negligence action, and brought
  a products liability suit on its behalf.
\In
  September 2000 Ross Marine terminated Browderâ€™s employment.Â  Attorneys Query
  and Gliserman formed an LLC (Firm) with attorney Sautter in 2002, and the Firm
  undertook to represent Browder in a Workerâ€™s Compensation proceeding.[2]Â 
  In August 2003, Browder, represented by the Firm, filed an employment suit
  against Ross Marine (the Browder case).Â  The merits of Browder were sent to arbitration.[3]Â  
Ross
  Marine sought to stay the Browder arbitration pending resolution of its
  request for an injunction preventing the Firm from representing Browder
  because, Ross Marine claimed, the Firm had a disqualifying conflict of
  interest.Â  In the Browder case, the circuit court issued an order
  denying Ross Marineâ€™s request to enjoin the Firm from representing Browder,
  holding, among other things, that:

  
    1)
    Ross Marine has failed to offer
  any proof that the [Firm]…represented Ross Marine in matters related to Mr.
  Browder’s termination or other claims detailed in the Browder complaint;
  
  
  
    2)
    Ross Marine has failed to offer
  any proof that any of the attorneys of the firm will be called on to use any
  information acquired in the previous representation to the detriment of Ross
  Marine, or that the attorneys ever acquired any information in the previous
  representation that could be used adversely to the interests of Ross Marine or
  any of the other defendants or for the benefit of Browder in the instant case;
  
  
  
    3)
     I find that Ross Marine has failed
  to establish that they will suffer irreparable harm if the case moves forward
  and the [Firm] continues to represent plaintiff David Browder.  By review of
  the entire record, I note that Ross Marine has had the ample time of
  approximately a year from the filing of this case to the present to fully
  develop their conflict position and submit the same for the Court’s review and
  consideration,  I find that Ross Marine has failed to establish a likelihood of
  success on the merits of their conflict allegations;
  
  
  
    4)
     I find the defendants have failed
  to offer any proof that attorney Query is likely to be a material witness in
  the instant case;
  
  
  
    5)
     I conclude that the [Firm] and
  their members did not breach or violate Rule 407, SCACR, Rules 1.7 and 1.9 of
  the South Carolina Rules of Professional Conduct.
  

 
Ross
  Marine appealed this order to the Court of Appeals.
The Court of
  Appeals heard the Browder appeal in November 2005 and affirmed the
  circuit court order in an unpublished opinion filed in December 2005.Â  Browder
    v. Ross Marine, Op. No. 2005-UP-613 (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 8,
  2005).Â  This Court denied certiorari in March 2007.
While the Browder case was pending in circuit court, four of the six Browder defendants
  filed this suit against the Firm, styling it as a request for injunctive and
  declaratory relief as well as for negligence,[4] seeking: a stay of the Browder arbitration;[5] an injunction disqualifying the Firm from representing Browder in the Browder case; a declaration that there is a disqualifying conflict; damages; and
  attorneys fees.Â  The circuit court dismissed the suit both on the merits, i.e.
  that there is no conflict of interest, and because the same issue was pending
  in the Browder case,[6] denied any further discovery, and awarded the Firm costs.Â  On reconsideration,
  the special circuit judge reiterated that he was dismissing both the
  declaratory judgment action and the negligence action for a failure of proof,
  but deleted the requirement that Ross Marine pay costs.[7]Â 
  Ross Marine then appealed.
This appeal was
  filed after the Court of Appeals had decided the Browder appeal, but
  while certiorari was pending in this Court.Â  The Court of Appeals held the
  present appeal in abeyance pending this Courtâ€™s disposition of the Browder certiorari request.Â  After certiorari was denied, the Court of Appeals issued
  an order permitting the disposition of the Browder appeal and certiorari
  to be briefed in this appeal, which was subsequently transferred to this Court.
ISSUE/ANALYSIS
The issue in this
  suit is whether the Firm has a disqualifying conflict of interest, which is the
  same question litigated in the Browder appeal.Â  As the Browder appeal has been concluded, we affirm the dismissal of this suit on the basis of
  collateral estoppel.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR (court can affirm on any
  ground appearing in the record).Â  â€œWhen an issue has been actually litigated
  and determined by a valid and final judgment, the determination is conclusive
  in a subsequent action whether on the same or a different claim.â€Â  Zurcher
    v. Bilton, supra.Â  Here, the claims are identical: that the Firm has
  a conflict of interest such that it cannot represent Browder in his employment
  suit against Ross Marine.
Furthermore,
  collateral estoppel should not be invoked unless the party was afforded a full
  and fair opportunity to litigate the issue in the first case.Â  Zurcher, supra.Â 
  In the Browder order, the circuit court judge held that â€œRoss Marine has
  had the ample time of approximately a year from the filing of this case until
  the present to fully develop their conflict positionâ€¦.â€Â  On appeal, appellants
  did not challenge that finding, and it is too late to allege now that they were
  not afforded a full and fair opportunity to litigate the conflict claim in the Browder case.
CONCLUSION
The issue
  raised here and in Browder is identical, and Ross Marine had a full and
  fair opportunity to litigate it in Browder.Â  Accordingly, collateral
  estoppel bars this suit.Â  Zurcher v. Bilton, supra.Â  The circuit
  court order is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We will refer to the appellants collectively as Ross Marine.
[2] The filing of the workers compensation claim preceded the formation of the LLC.
[3] It appears that the arbitration has not yet taken place.
[4] The negligence claim is predicated on the Firmâ€™s alleged breach of its duty to
  Ross Marine not to engage in representation where there is a conflict of
interest.
[5] Note that Browder is not a party to the Ross Marine suit.
[6] Browder was on appeal when the Ross Marine order was filed.
[7] In light of the language used in the order on rehearing, the ruling below is
  best viewed as one granting summary judgment since the special circuit judge
  considered matters outside the pleadings in holding there was no evidence of
any conflict.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        South Carolina
          Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, Appellant,
        v.
        Howard Durham
          and Cherie Durham, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26579
  Heard November 19, 2008 - Filed January
12, 2009 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        John
          Dwight Hudson, of Hudson Law Office, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
        Dirk
          Julius Derrick, of Conway, for Respondents.
      
    
  


ACTING JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant
  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company (Appellant) filed this
  declaratory judgment action seeking a declaration that its policy did not cover
  the damage to Howard and Cherie Durhamâ€™s (Respondents) swimming pool when it
  â€œfloatedâ€ after Respondents drained the pool.Â  The parties agreed to submit the
  case to the circuit court which found that the policy covered the damage to the
  pool.Â  We find that the policy exclusions apply and so reverse the order of the
  circuit court.

FACTS

Respondentsâ€™
  home and in-ground pool are located in Horry County and were covered by a
  homeownerâ€™s policy of insurance issued by Appellant.Â  At one point, Respondents
  drained the water from their pool to empty it in order to clean the pool.Â 
  Before the pool was fully emptied, the area experienced rainfall over a
  four-day period.Â  The pool was then fully emptied and, within two to three days
  of being fully emptied, the pool â€œfloatedâ€ out of its foundation and rose from
  the ground, causing damage to the pool and deck.
Respondentsâ€™
  expert explained that pressure from underground water, the presence and depth
  of which varies from place to place, will result in a pool â€œfloatingâ€ if the
  pool is drained.Â  â€œFloatingâ€ can be avoided by unscrewing a plug in the drain
  system, which allows the ground water that is higher than the base of the pool
  to enter and relieve pressure upon the pool.
Respondentsâ€™
  filed a claim under their homeownerâ€™s policy.Â  Both parties agreed that the policy
  applied to the swimming pool, but Appellant denied coverage based on two
  sections of the policy.Â  The relevant language is as follows:

  Section
    I - Perils Insured Against
  Coverage
    A - Dwelling and 
  Coverage
    B - Other Structures
  We
    insure against risks of direct physical loss to property described in Coverages
    A and B.Â  However, we do not insure loss:
  . . .
  2.
    caused by:
  . . .
  b.
    freezing, thawing, pressure or weight of water, ice, hail, snow or sleet,
    whether driven by wind or not, to a:
  (1)
    fence, pavement, deck, patio, or swimming pool.
  . . .
  e. these
    below:
  . . .
  (6)
    settling, cracking, shrinking, bulging or expansion of driveways, pavements,
    patios, foundations, walls, floors, roofs or ceilings.
  . . . 
  Section
    I - Exclusions
  We do
    not insure for loss caused directly or indirectly by any of the following.Â 
    Such loss is excluded regardless of any other cause or event contributing
    concurrently or in any sequence to the loss.
  3. Water
    Damage, meaning:
  . . . 
  c. water
    below the surface of the ground, including water which exerts pressure on or
    seeps or leaks through a building, sidewalk, driveway, foundation, swimming
    pool or other structure.

The
  parties agreed to stipulations on facts and evidence and submitted the case to
  the circuit court for decision.Â  The court found in favor of Respondents and
  awarded policy limits.Â  This appeal followed.
ISSUE
Is the damage to
Respondentsâ€™ pool and deck subject to an exclusion in the insurance policy?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
This
  case raises a novel question of law in South Carolina.Â  In such a case, the
  appellate court is free to decide the question with no particular deference to
  the lower court. Iâ€™On, LLC v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 411,
  526 S.E.2d 716, 719 (2000) (citing S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 5; S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1976 & Supp. 2005).Â  
ANALYSIS
The
  primary point of contention in this case is what â€œcausedâ€ Respondentsâ€™ pool to
  â€œfloat.â€Â  Appellant contends that the pool â€œfloatedâ€ because of the presence of
  underground water pressure in conjunction with Respondents draining the pool
  without pulling the plug.Â  In Appellantâ€™s view, if the water pressure was a
  factor of any kind in causing the loss, even an indirect or remote one, the language
  of the policy excludes the loss.
A. The circuit court
  improperly defined the term â€œcause.â€
The
  circuit court found that the cause of the pool â€œfloatingâ€ was the Respondents
  removing all of the water without removing the plug.Â  The court noted that the
  word â€œcauseâ€ is not defined in the Policy and cited State Farm Fire & Casualty
    Co. v. Barrett, 340 S.C. 1, 530 S.E.2d 132 (Ct. App. 2000), for the
  proposition that â€œ[w]here a term is not defined in an insurance policy, it is
  to be defined according to the usual understanding of the termâ€™s significance
  to the ordinary person.â€ Id. at 8, 530 S.E.2d at 136.Â  The circuit court
  then continued, â€œ[t]he meaning of the pivotal word â€˜causeâ€™ has primarily
  developed in the conte[x]t of tort and insurance law where causation is an
  essential element in establishing liabilityâ€ and applied tests utilized in
  determining legal causation.Â  Citing the reasoning of Bebber v. CAN
    Insurance Companies, 189 Misc.2d 42, 729 N.Y.S.2d 844 (N.Y. Sup. Ct. 2001), the court found that the draining was a â€œbut forâ€ cause of the â€œfloatingâ€ and
  that the underground water pressure was a natural, static force which could not
  be an intervening cause.Â  The court also concluded that the rainfall prior to
  the pool â€œfloatingâ€ was not a factor, since the parties stipulated that the
  hydrostatic pressure was present both before and after the pool was emptied.
Among other points,
  Appellant complains that the circuit court incorrectly defined the term â€œcauseâ€
  in construing the policy.Â  We agree.Â  The circuit court correctly noted that
  the term â€œcauseâ€ is not defined by the policy and that in such case the court
  must define the term according to the usual understanding of the termâ€™s
  significance to the ordinary person.Â  However, rather than attempting to
  ascertain the understanding to the ordinary person, the court looked instead to
  tort law and tests â€œutilized in determining legal causation.â€
â€œCauseâ€
  in the context of an insurance policy and in the usual understanding of the
  termâ€™s significance to the ordinary person is not the same as legal causation. See 7 Couch on Insurance 3d Â§ 101:40 (Steven Plitt, et al., eds., 2008).Â 
  The circuit court noted that â€œ[a] circumstance which merely â€˜sets the stateâ€™ is
  not regarded as being a proximate cause merely because the circumstance made
  possibl[e] the subsequent loss.â€ (citing Couch on Insurance, 2nd,
  sec. 74.713; Bebber, supra).Â  Yet the usual understanding of the
  word â€œcauseâ€ does not require that an event or condition be the proximate
  cause.Â  The American Heritage Dictionary defines â€œcauseâ€ as â€œ[s]omething
  that produces an effect, result, or consequenceâ€ and â€œ[t]he person, event, or
  condition responsible for an action or result.â€Â  In applying this definition of
  â€œcauseâ€ the â€œbut forâ€ test is appropriate.Â  While it is true, as the Bebber court noted, that â€œbut forâ€ the plaintiffâ€™s drainage of the pool the damage
  would not have occurred, it is also true that â€œbut forâ€ the underground water
  pressure, the damage would not have occurred.Â  Therefore, the underground water
  pressure was a â€œcauseâ€ of the damage.Â  
However,
  the pressure was certainly not the sole cause of the â€œfloating.â€Â  Case law from
  other jurisdictions demonstrates two main tests for determining coverage where
  the loss is the result of multiple causes.Â  The majority of jurisdictions
  follow the efficient proximate cause doctrine which provides that in
  circumstances with two or more identifiable causes, the court looks to the
  cause which is determined to have set the chain of events in motion. See Amherst Country Club, Inc. v. Harleysville Worcester Ins. Co., 561
  F.Supp.2d 138, 150 (D.N.H. 2008).Â  If this â€œefficient proximate causeâ€ is
  covered under the terms of the policy, then the loss is covered. Id.Â  The minority rule is the concurrent cause rule, which asks whether one of the
  causes of a loss is covered. Id.Â  If so, then the loss is covered
  notwithstanding the fact that there is also an excluded cause in the chain of
  causation. Id.Â  In the instant case, neither doctrine applies since the
  policy contains an anti-concurrent causation clause.Â  The exclusion provides
  that â€œ[s]uch loss is excluded regardless of any other cause or event
  contributing concurrently or in any sequence to the loss.â€Â  Consequently,
  though the underground water pressure was not the sole cause of the loss or
  even the efficient proximate cause, it was a cause of the loss and so, the
  exclusion applies.
B. Exclusion applies to loss resulting from a
  condition existing at the time at which the policy was made. 
In
  finding coverage, the circuit court found that the exclusion regarding water
  damage did not contemplate Respondentsâ€™ situation, since the definitions of
  water damage describe events or conditions not existing at the time the policy
  was written, such as floods, waves, etc.Â  We find that the language of the
  water damage exclusion does not support the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation.
The
  water damage provision excludes coverage for loss caused by â€œwater below the
  surface of the ground, including water which exerts pressure on or seeps or
  leaks through a . . . swimming pool or other structure.â€Â  Nothing in the
  language excludes an existing condition as a cause.Â  Moreover, the use of the
  word â€œexertsâ€ in the present tense suggests that an existing condition is
  contemplated by the exclusion.
CONCLUSION
Underground
  water pressure was at least one cause of the damage to Respondentsâ€™ pool.Â 
  Under the exclusions and anti-concurrent causation clause of the policy, the
  loss is excluded from coverage.Â  We therefore reverse the order of the circuit
court. 

REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Adam Bickham, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26581
  Heard October 7, 2008 - Filed January 12,
2009Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief
          Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on
          Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General William
          M. Blitch, Jr., all of Columbia and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington,
          for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES: This
  is an appeal from the acceptance of an Alford plea to the charge of
  criminal sexual conduct with a minor (CSCM) in the first degree.Â  Appellant
  entered guilty pleas to two counts of CSCM in the second degree and entered an Alford plea to one count of CSCM in the first degree.Â  The plea judge accepted the
  pleas and sentenced Appellant. Â Appellant contends that the plea judge erred in
  refusing to allow Appellant to withdraw his Alford plea to CSCM in the
  first degree.Â  We disagree and affirm. 
FACTS
Appellant
  was indicted on two counts of CSCM in the second degree and one count of CSCM
  in the first degree.Â  The assistant solicitor (Solicitor) offered Appellant the
  option to plead guilty to the two counts of CSCM in the second degree and to
  plead under North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25, 91 S.Ct. 160 (1970),
  to CSCM in the first degree.Â  Solicitor stated that if Appellant did not accept
  the plea deal, then he would proceed to call the cases to trial separately in
  order to subject Appellant to sentence enhancements and punishment of life
  without the possibility of parole under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45.[1]Â  
Appellant
  pled guilty to the charges of CSCM in the second degree and entered an Alford plea to CSCM in the first degree.Â  The judge explained to Appellant that by
  pleading to the crimes, he faced a possible sentence of between zero and 70
  years in prison and that he must serve at least 85 percent of the sentence.Â  
The plea judge then found that Appellantâ€™s decisions
  to plead guilty to the charges of CSCM in the second degree were knowingly,
  voluntarily, and intelligently made, and accepted both pleas.Â  The judge then
  began to address Appellantâ€™s Alford plea, at which point Appellantâ€™s
  counsel (Counsel) interjected and, after lengthy discussion, moved to withdraw
  the Alford plea.Â  Counsel explained her position to the court:

  
    Counsel:
    Judge, [the motion for withdrawal] is
  based on the fact that if I had ever been presented with an option to separate
  [the charges] in any way, I would have always believed we should have gone to
  trial on [the charge of CSCM in the first degree] and have entered guilty pleas
  to the two C.S.C. seconds.  I have not only not been given that option; I have
  been told repeatedly I do not have that option.  He either pleads two guilties
  and one Alford or the solicitor is going to proceed in a different
  manner on the two firsts.  I understand we’re in front of the court now and we
  may be in a different posture, but that’s why we’re standing in front of you
  like this because I was told that was not an option and that if I wanted . . . 
    
    
  
  
    The Court:
    The options that you were given were what
  to present to me.  Nobody controls my options as to what plea I accept or don’t
  accept.
    
    
  
  
    Counsel: 
    No, judge, but the option I was given is
  that he could plead on the first one and then under the new law [the State] was
  going to serve him with life without parole notice and he had a slam-dunk case
  on that other one.  The girl is pregnant, no question about it, and he would -
  - he would get life without parole.  That was essentially what was presented to
  me, and there was no variation from that other than us enter these pleas as we
  are in the process of trying to do today.
    
    
  
  
    . . . 
    
    
  
  
    The Court: 
    And so you advised your client that those
  were the potential consequences if he didn’t plead to all of them as a package.
    
    
  
  
    Counsel:
    Yes, sir.
      
    
  
  
    The Court:
    And so when he made the decision to plead
  guilty [sic] to the charge against - - involving [the charge of CSCM in the
  first degree] and up until the point where . . . the solicitor was no longer
  able to call . . . the July to September charge [of CSCM in the second degree]
  as the second charge, up until that point it was his intention and his desire
  to plead guilty [sic] to the charge involving [CSCM in the first degree]. 
  Correct?
    
    
  
  
    Counsel: 
     Yes, sir, based - - yes, sir.
      
    
  

The plea judge offered to refuse to accept all three
  pleas, but Counsel declined.Â  Ultimately, the judge refused to allow Counsel to
withdraw only the Alford plea and instead accepted the plea.
ISSUE
Did
  the plea judge err in denying Appellantâ€™s motion to withdraw his Alford plea?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The withdrawal of a guilty plea is generally within
  the sound discretion of the trial judge. State v. Riddle, 278 S.C. 148,
  150, 292 S.E.2d 795, 796 (1982).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial
  courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of
  law. State v. Lopez, 352 S.C. 373, 378, 574 S.E.2d 210, 212 (Ct. App.
  2002).
ANALYSIS
Appellant bears the burden on appeal of showing an
  abuse of discretion.Â  Appellant has made no such showing and so, we affirm.
Solicitor offered Appellant the chance to enter an Alford plea to the charge of CSCM in the first degree as part of a package deal.Â  Upon
  Counselâ€™s interjection, the plea judge advised that he would not allow
  withdrawal of only the Alford plea, but rather would allow same in
  conjunction with withdrawal of all three pleas, so as to retain the integrity
  of the package. Â Counsel declined, and admitted that if Solicitor had the power
  to call all three cases, then Appellant intended to follow through with his Alford plea.Â  The plea judge did not abuse his discretion in retaining the package
  deal by refusing to allow withdrawal of only the Alford plea.[2]
CONCLUSION
The plea judge did not abuse his discretion in
  refusing to allow withdrawal of the Alford plea alone.Â  Therefore, we
  affirm.
AFFIRMED.
WALLER, J., concurs. KITTREDGE, J., concurring in a
separate opinion in which TOAL, C.J. and BEATTY, J., concur.

JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â 
  I concur in result.Â  Prior to formal acceptance of the Alford plea, the
  plea judge formally accepted Appellantâ€™s guilty plea to two counts of criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor in the second degree.Â  Appellant sought to withdraw
  the Alford plea prior to formal acceptance of that plea.Â  I write
  separately because, in my judgment, in a typical guilty plea a defendant has a
  right to withdraw a guilty plea prior to formal acceptance by the plea judge.Â  Harden
    v. State, 453 So.2d 550, 550-51 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1984) (â€œUntil formal
  acceptance has occurred, the plea binds no one: not the defendant, the
  prosecutor, or the court . . . . Â [F]ormal acceptance of a plea occurs when the
  trial court affirmatively states to the parties, in open court and for the
  record, that the court accepts the plea.â€) (internal citations omitted); State
    v. Creamer, 161 S.W.3d 420, 425 (Mo. Ct. App. 2005) (â€œUp until acceptance
  of the guilty plea by the trial court, a defendant has unfettered latitude to
  withdraw his plea.â€); see also Fed.
  R. Crim. P. 11(d)(1) (â€œA defendant may withdraw a plea of guilty or nolo
  contendere . . . before the court accepts the plea, for any reason or no reason
  . . . .â€).Â  Withdrawal of a guilty plea prior to formal acceptance is,
  therefore, generally a matter of right and not a matter within the plea judgeâ€™s
  discretion.Â  This case, however, does not present the typical situation.Â  In
  light of the package deal associated with all charges and the plea judgeâ€™s
  offer for Appellant to withdraw all pleas, I agree with the result reached by
  the majority.
TOAL, C.J., and BEATTY, J., concur.


[1] Section 17-25-45 provides that upon a conviction for a â€œmost serious offenseâ€ a
  person must be sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole
  if the person has a prior conviction for a â€œmost serious offense.â€Â  Section
  17-25-45(C) provides that both CSCM in the first and second degree are â€œmost
  seriousâ€ offenses.Â  Both Solicitor and Appellantâ€™s counsel believed that
  Appellant could have received a sentence for life without parole under Â§
  17-25-45 if convicted separately on the three charges of CSCM.Â  We express no
  opinion as to the application of the statute to Appellantâ€™s situation as that
  matter is not before us.
[2] Appellant also seems to argue that he did not
  understand the consequences of the plea since Counsel and Solicitor stated that
  he faced life without parole (LWOP) if he did not accept the Stateâ€™s
  â€œall-or-nothingâ€ deal.Â  Appellant contends that he was, in fact, not eligible
  for LWOP under then-existing law and therefore, the judge abused his discretion
  in refusing to allow Appellant to withdraw the plea.Â  This argument is not
  properly preserved since it was not presented at Appellantâ€™s plea hearing. See State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 108, 292 S.E.2d 598, 599 (1982)
  (failure to assert before trial court that plea was not knowing and intelligent
  precludes consideration of the issue on appeal).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Kevin Mercer, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26582
  Heard October 7, 2008 - Filed January 12,
2009Â Â  

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        Deputy
          Chief Appellate Defender for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, and Melissa Jane Reed Kimbrough, of
          Kimbrough & Taggart, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General S.
          Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE KITTREDGE: Â Â Â Â  This is a mandatory appeal from a sentence of death.Â  On March 16,
  2002, Army recruiter Sergeant First Class Tracy Davis was gunned down outside
  his apartment in Lexington County, South Carolina.Â  Kevin Mercer (Mercer) was
  convicted of murder, armed robbery, and possession of a firearm in the commission
  of a violent crime, and sentenced to death.Â  In his appeal, Mercer challenges:
  (1) the disqualification of a juror; (2) the exclusion of evidence, both in the
  guilt and sentencing phases; (3) the denial of his post-trial motion for
  additional funds to test gloves for gunshot residue; and (4) the denial of his
  post-trial motion for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence.Â  We
  affirm.Â  
I.
Prior
  to his death, Sergeant First Class Tracy Davis (Davis) lived near Columbia, South Carolina, where he served as an active-duty member of the United States
  Army.Â  He was attached to Fort Jackson where he trained Army recruiters. 
On
  the evening of March 16, 2002, Davis arrived home at approximately 11:30 P.M. to
  the Raintree Apartments.Â  As was his custom, he backed his vehicle, a white
  Lincoln Navigator, into a parking spot outside his apartment.Â  According to a
  witness, after exiting his truck, Davis encountered a man and words were
  apparently exchanged. 
The
  witness to the encounter was Davisâ€™s roommate, Sergeant First Class Clifton
  Magwood (Magwood).Â  Magwood witnessed the confrontation from an apartment
  window. Â Magwoodâ€™s room is on the second floor of the apartment, and his window
  looks out over the parking lot.Â  Magwood testified that he heard a disturbance,
  got out of bed, looked through his blinds and observed Davis with a heavyset
  man, apparently armed with a handgun, demanding the keys to Davisâ€™s vehicle.Â 
  Magwood saw the robber forcing Davis toward the rear of the vehicle and heard Davis tell the armed man, â€œAll right.Â  Iâ€™ll give it to you.â€
Magwood
  left his vantage point to call 911 and summon help.Â  The 911 call was logged at
  11:32 P.M. Shortly thereafter, while running downstairs to help his roommate,
  Magwood heard a gunshot; he hurried outside to find Davis lying in the bushes
  near the parking lot.Â  Magwood saw Davisâ€™s Navigator leaving the apartment
  complex.Â  Davis died as a result of a gunshot to the back of the head.
Magwood
  only saw one individual confront Davis with a gun. Although Magwood only saw
  the individual from the back, he provided an immediate and detailed description
  of the assailant to law enforcement.Â  The suspect was described as â€œa black maleâ€;
  â€œbroad shouldersâ€; â€œheavy build, muscularâ€; anywhere from 5â€™11â€™â€™ to 6â€™2â€ and
  weighing â€œ215 to 225.â€Â  Magwood further described the suspectâ€™s clothing as â€œa
  dark outfit, could be jean or denim or some type of dark outfit with a dark
  hat.â€ 
Magwoodâ€™s
  detailed description of the killer, along with a description of the Navigator,
  was dispatched to all officers in the vicinity, by way of a â€œbe on the
  lookout,â€ commonly referred to as a BOLO.Â  Deputy Dennis Stazer of the
  Lexington County Sheriffâ€™s Office responded to the BOLO broadcast by
  positioning his patrol car (at 11:42 P.M.) at what he believed could be an
  intercept position on a nearby interstate, I-20.Â  Within minutes, a white
  Navigator drove past Deputy Stazerâ€™s location.Â  Deputy Stazer pulled in behind
  the suspect vehicle and initiated a traffic stop at 11:50 P.M.Â Â  Â Â 
There
  were two black males in the Navigator, Mercer in the driverâ€™s seat and Marcus
  Thompson in the front passengerâ€™s seat. Deputy Stazer utilized his patrol carâ€™s
  â€œlight bar . . . to light up the interior of the [Navigator].â€ Â Deputy Stazer
  approached the driverâ€™s side and asked the driver (Mercer) for his license and
  registration.Â  Mercer produced his license, but could not find the vehicle
  registration.Â  Mercer eventually located a receipt from a car dealership and
  handed it to Deputy Stazer.Â  The receipt confirmed that the Navigator belonged
  to the murder victim, Davis.Â  Mercer and Thompson were taken into custody.Â  
Inside
  the Navigator, a .357 caliber handgun was retrieved from under the driverâ€™s
  seat.[1]Â 
  Testing matched the handgun to the bullet removed from Davis during the
  autopsy.Â  Gunshot residue (GSR) testing done on Mercerâ€™s hands revealed
  materials considered to be consistent with GSR, although the test results were
  not conclusive.Â  Testing done on Thompsonâ€™s hands resulted in a negative test
  for GSR.Â  Four gloves (two pairs) were found in Thompsonâ€™s possession but were
  not tested for GSR.Â  As Thompson was removed from the vehicle, a plastic bag
  containing fourteen .357 bullets â€œfell out of his pants legs.â€ 
Mercer
  matched the detailed description of the assailant furnished by Magwood.Â  Mercer
  is 5 feet 10 inches tall and weighs 220 pounds.[2] The officers on the scene of the arrest confirmed that Mercer is a broad-shouldered,
  muscular individual, consistent with Magwoodâ€™s description.Â  Mercer was
  arrested wearing a â€œdark[,] . . . like a denim . . . jean jacket outfitâ€; he
  was also wearing â€œa black . . . baseball style cap.â€
Conversely,
  Thompson is â€œvery slenderâ€ and â€œnarrow-shoulderedâ€ and weighs about 150 pounds.
  Â At the time of his arrest, Thompson was wearing â€œa black tee shirt that was
  over a white tee shirt,â€ with the white tee shirt conspicuously sticking out
  from the black tee shirt.Â  Thompson was not wearing a hat.
Mercer
  and Thompson were charged with murder, armed robbery, possession of a firearm during

  at 619, 513 S.E.2d at 99.Â  In denying the post-trial motion as to the guilt
  phase, the trial court observed that the jury was charged, without objection,
  on the law of â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â  In denying the post-trial
  motion as to the sentencing phase, the trial court observed that the jury was
  charged that it could recommend a death sentence only if it found that Mercer
  was the triggerman.[11] 
Mercer
  takes issue with the denial of his post-trial motion.Â  Mercer posits a
  different view of the facts.Â  Mercer, in essence, invites this Court to make
  different credibility determinations, especially with respect to Fuller.Â  Beyond
  Fuller, it is argued that the trial court had a valid reason not to believe
  cellmate Johnston over Fuller, for Johnston was facing life imprisonment with a
  pending burglary first-degree charge.[12]Â 
  We respectfully decline Mercerâ€™s invitation to engage in de novo fact
  finding.Â Â  We further reject the suggestion to ignore the trial courtâ€™s gatekeeping
  role in post-trial after-discovered evidence motions. 

  The
    credibility of newly-discovered evidence offered in support of a motion for a
    new trial is a matter for determination by the circuit judge to whom it is
    offered.Â  In him, not this court, resides the power to weigh such evidence; and
    his judgment thereabout will not be disturbed except for error of law or abuse
    of discretion.

Mayfield, 235 S.C. at 34-35, 109 S.E.2d at 729.Â  
To
  accept Mercerâ€™s premise that a jury must weigh the conflicting evidence ignores
  the State v. Spann factors and the gatekeeping role of the trial court
  as outlined in many cases, including State v. Mayfield.Â  Moreover, the
  approach advanced by Mercer confuses the applicable standard in post-trial
  after-discovered evidence motions with the admissibility of third-party guilt
  evidence at trial. 
The
  question before us, then, is whether the trial courtâ€™s denial of the post-trial
  motion amounts to an abuse of discretion.Â  We hold it does not.Â  In so ruling,
  we are sensitive to the notion that a mere finding of a witnessâ€™s lack of
  credibility does not complete the analysis, because a witness may lack persuasive
  credibility and still create reasonable doubt.Â  This sensitivity forms part of
  our consideration.Â  We have drawn the line, however, with Mercerâ€™s desire to
  use Fullerâ€™s testimony for â€œresidual doubtâ€ as to guilt in the sentencing
  phase. Franklin v. Lynaugh, 487 U.S. 164, 172-74 (1988) (clarifying Eighth
  Amendment jurisprudence by noting that a state is not constitutionally required
  to allow a capital defendant to submit â€œresidual doubtâ€ mitigation evidence in
  the sentencing phase of a capital case).Â  We affirm the denial of Mercerâ€™s
  post-trial motion based on after-discovered evidence. 
VII.
We
  have conducted the statutorily mandated review under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25
  (2003).Â  We find the sentence of death was not imposed under the influence of passion,
  prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor.Â  We further find that the evidence
  supports the juryâ€™s finding of a statutory aggravating circumstance, and that
  the sentence of death is proportionate to sentences imposed under similar
  situations.Â  State v. Huggins, 336 S.C. 200, 519 S.E.2d 574 (1999); State
    v. McWee, 322 S.C. 387, 472 S.E.2d 235 (1996).Â  Mercerâ€™s convictions and
sentence of death are

AFFIRMED.
  Â Â Â Â 
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Deputy Stazer did not testify to seeing a
  handgun when he first approached the driverâ€™s window.Â  Moreover, Deputy Stazer,
  who â€œhad to keep [his] eyes on both of them,â€ saw no movement from either
  Mercer or Thompson.Â  Deputy Stazer testified that had there been any movement
  in the vehicle he considered as a threat, he would have responded with deadly
  force.Â  This testimony concerning the lack of movement, especially by Thompson,
  acquires relevance when read in context with Mercerâ€™s post-trial motion for a
  new trial based on after-discovered evidence.
[2] This height and weight is taken from Mercerâ€™s
  driverâ€™s license which he produced to Deputy Stazer.Â  There is nothing in the
  record that contradicts this description. 
[3] We use the pseudonym John Doe. 
[4] Neither the State nor Mercer called Thompson
  as a witness.
[5] Although this evidence was not admissible, we
  do recognize that defense counsel, in her opening remarks to the jury, referred
  to Thompsonâ€™s reduced charges and bond status.Â  According to counselâ€™s opening
  statement, â€œWe donâ€™t know where [Thompson] is.Â  Last time I heard he was out on
  bond.Â  Last time I heard he wasnâ€™t even charged with murder or armed robbery.Â 
  That wasnâ€™t how it started out.Â  He was charged with all the same things that
Kevin Mercer was.â€
[6] SPECT is an acronym for single-photon emission
  computerized tomography.Â  Richard E. Redding, The Brain-Disordered
    Defendant: Neuroscience and Legal Insanity in the Twenty-First Century, 56 Am. U. L. Rev. 51, 121 (2006).Â  According to Dr. Steedman, â€œa spect scan is a . . . nuclear medicine
  study.Â  It is . . . a way of looking at the function of somebodyâ€™s brain in
  terms of how much blood flow is running through the cortex.Â  Itâ€™s mainly useful
  in detecting whether there are asymmetries and regional differences in blood
  flow . . . to parts of the brain which indicates . . . how hard those parts of
  the brain are working.â€Â  An abnormal spect
  scan means there is either increased or decreased blood flow to a
  certain area in the brain.Â  A decreased flow of blood to a particular region of
  the brain may be referred to as an abnormality and may be associated with
  general cognitive deficiencies and learning disorders.Â  
[7] This Court reminds the bench and bar of the  importance of a meaningful mitigation defense and, concomitantly, the ability  of a capital defendant to fully present mitigation evidence.  See Council v.  State, __ S.C. __, __ S.E.2d __ (2008), Op. No. 26543 (S.C. Sup. Ct. re-filed Dec. 29, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 48 at 12) (relying in large part upon Wiggins  v. Smith, 539 U.S. 510 (2003), this Court determined that counsel’s failure  to adequately investigate and present mitigating evidence resulted in the  ineffective assistance of counsel requiring a new sentencing hearing).  The  trial courts, vested with considerable discretion in evidentiary matters, must  not neglect the due process implications involved in a capital defendant’s  right to present mitigation evidence.
[8] In this case, the State repeatedly asked the
  trial court to order Mercer to disclose his experts and to require a written
  report from his experts.Â  The trial court refused to order defense experts to
  produce written reports.Â  State v. Northcutt, 372 S.C. 207, 216-17, 641
  S.E.2d 873, 878 (2007) (holding that Rule 5, SCRCrimP, provides no basis for a
  trial court to require the creation of written defense expert reports for
  disclosure to the State).Â  The trial court ultimately relented to the Stateâ€™s
  discovery requests by ordering the parties to meet and attempt to resolve the
  impasse.Â  This was done, and because defense counsel failed to hit the bullâ€™s
  eye concerning Dr. Steedmanâ€™s precise opinion regarding the SPECT Scan study,
  the State cried foul.Â  The Stateâ€™s claim of unfair surprise is meritless. Â 
[9] The
  analytical framework at play in this post-trial motion (imposing on the trial
  judge a gate-keeping role in making credibility determinations) stands in stark
  contrast to the admissibility of third-party guilt evidence at trial.Â  Provided
  threshold admissibility is met, third-party guilt evidence may not be excluded
  based on the trial courtâ€™s view of the evidence or the perceived â€œstrengthâ€ of
  the Stateâ€™s case. Holmes v. South Carolina, 547 U.S. 319, 330-31 (2006)
  (reversing the exclusion of evidence in a criminal trial and holding that the
  trial court may not exclude evidence of third-party guilt based upon a
  determination of the strength of the Stateâ€™s evidence).Â Â Â  
[10] This inconsistency concerns Mercerâ€™s possession
  of the murder weapon immediately after the murder as he exited the apartment
  complex in Davisâ€™s Navigator.Â  
[11] The trial court charged the jury:Â  

  Now,
    you will recall that in the guilt phase of the trial I charged you on the
    concept of the hand of one is the hand of all.Â  That concept does not apply in
    this penalty phase of the trial. . . .Â  Before you may consider imposing the
    death penalty, you must first find that the State has proven beyond a
    reasonable doubt that the defendant, Kevin J. Mercer, fired the shot that
    killed the victim.Â  If you find that the State has failed to prove that Kevin
    J. Mercer fired that shot, then you may not impose the death penalty but you
    must impose a life sentence.Â  

[12] As between Johnston and Fuller, the trial court
  recalled Johnstonâ€™s testimony to the effect that â€œFuller thought he could
  benefit from fabricating a story about Thompson shooting Sergeant Davis.â€Â 
  While the record confirms that Fuller was seeking â€œhelpâ€ with his charges, Johnston did not testify to any such â€œfabricationâ€ admission by Fuller.Â  Mercer is correct
  in challenging the trial courtâ€™s erroneous finding in this regard.Â  We view the
  error as insignificant.Â  The strong findings of the trial court against
  Fullerâ€™s credibility cannot reasonably be said to be dependent on this one
  finding.Â  This finding does not form a meaningful part of the trial courtâ€™s
  order, for it stands alone in an otherwise coherent analysis.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of William H. Jordan, Respondent.

ORDER

The Office of Disciplinary Counsel asks this Court to place respondent, who practices law in Charleston, South Carolina, on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 17(a) and (b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR. Sidney Boone, Jr., Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility for respondent’s client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office accounts respondent may maintain. THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				William D.
      Curtis, Respondent,
				v.
				Brandon T.
      Blake, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26583
Heard November 6, 2008 - Filed January 20,
  2009
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Thomas
  J. Keaveny, II, and Bob J. Conley, both of Simons & Keaveny, of Charleston, for Petitioner.
				C.
  Bradley Hutto, of Williams & Williams, of Orangeburg, and Mark Brandon
  Tinsley, of Gooding & Gooding, of Allendale, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review an order of the Court of
  Appeals which dismissed the appeal of Petitioner Brandon Blake as untimely.Â  We
  find Petitionerâ€™s appeal was timely filed and, accordingly, we reverse and
  remand.
FACTS
A jury awarded
  Respondent, William Curtis, a $450,000 verdict for injuries sustained in an
  auto accident with Petitioner, Blake. Â Immediately following the verdict, on
  October 31, 2005, Blake requested to make post-trial motions at a later date.Â Â 
  The trial court ruled post-trial motions could be made in written form,
  stating, â€œWeâ€™ll have ten days to file any post-trial motions.Â  And yâ€™all can
  just send those to me in Spartanburg, and I will rule on those without the
  necessity of actual oral argument.â€Â  
On November 10,
  2005, the tenth day after the verdict, Blake served opposing counsel with a
  Rule 59(b) motion for new trial by placing it in the mail.Â  The motion was
  filed by the Orangeburg Clerk of Court five days later, on November 15, 2005.Â 
  Curtis responded, claiming the motion was untimely as it was not filed within
  the ten days allotted by the trial judge; the circuit court ruled the motion
  was timely but denied the motion for a new trial on the merits.Â  
Blakeâ€™s appeal to
  the Court of Appeals was dismissed by Judge Cureton on the ground that the
  appeal was untimely.Â  Judge Cureton ruled the motion had to be delivered to and
  received by the Clerk of Court no later than November 10, 2005 in order to
  comply with the trial courtâ€™s instructions.Â Â  As it did not, Judge Cureton
  found the late-filed motion did not stay the time for service of the notice of
  appeal, such that the appeal was untimely.[1]Â 
  On motion for reconsideration, a three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals
  affirmed.Â  
ISSUE
Did the Court of
  Appeals err in dismissing the appeal as untimely where the motion for a new
  trial was served on opposing counsel on the tenth day after trial?Â  

DISCUSSION
A â€œmotion for a new
  trial shall be made promptly after the jury is discharged, or in the
  discretion of the court not later than 10 days thereafter.â€Â  Rule 59(b), SCRCP.
  Â (Emphasis supplied).Â  A timely Rule 59 motion stays the time for an appeal for
  all parties until receipt of written notice of entry of the order granting or
  denying such motion.Â  Elam v. SCDOT, 361 S.C. 9, 602 S.E.2d 772
  (2004).Â  The question here is whether the post-trial motion was â€œmadeâ€ at the
  time it was filed with the court, or when it was served on opposing counsel.Â 
  We find the motion was â€œmadeâ€ when it was placed in the mail for service on
  opposing counsel.Â Â Â  
The trial judge
  here exercised his discretion in allowing the parties ten days in which to make
  a post-trial motion.Â  The court then ruled the motion, which was served on the
  tenth day, was timely made.Â  We agree.Â  
Although Rule 59(b)
  does not define the term â€œmade,â€ other portions of Rule 59 utilize service as
  the effective date.Â  For example, Rule 59(c) sets for the Time for Serving
  Affidavits, stating, â€œ[w]hen a motion for new trial is based upon affidavits
  they shall be served with the motion.â€Â  Similarly, Rule 59(d) permits a court
  on its own initiative to â€œgrant a motion for a new trial, timely served. . .â€Â  Under
  Rule 59(e), â€œa motion to alter or amend the judgment shall be served not later
  than 10 days after receipt of written notice of the entry of the order.â€[2] Â Â Â Â 
Furthermore, this
  Court has previously held Rule 59(b) requires service of post trial
  motions within ten days after judgment.Â  See Diamond Jewelers v.
    Naegele Outdoor Advertising, 290 S.C. 260, 349 S.E.2d 888 (1985)
  (recognizing post-trial motions to amend, alter and for a new trial must be served
  not later than ten days after entry of judgment).Â  
Accordingly, we
  hold a motion for a new trial is timely so long as it is served within the time
  period allotted by the trial judge.[3]Â 
  We find the trial court properly held Blakeâ€™s motion for a new trial was timely.Â 
  We reinstate the appeal and remand the matter to the Court of Appeals for
  consideration on the merits.Â  
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 


[1]Â  Pursuant to Rule 59(f), the time for appeal is
  stayed by a timely Rule 59 motion.
[2] Â In contrast, the current federal version of
  Rule 59(b) specifically requires a new trial be filed no later than 10
  days after the entry of judgment, and Rule 59(c) and (e) also specifically
  require filing rather than service.Â  Prior to the Federal Rule
  59â€™s amendment in 1995, it was the date of service of the motion rather
  than the date of filing which was significant.Â  If service was timely, it was
  sufficient if the motion was filed within a reasonable time after service.Â Â  See Wright and Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure, Â§ 2812 (1995).
[3]Â  It is, however, within the trial courtâ€™s
  discretion whether to allow up to ten days for post-trial motions to be made.Â Â

title: Johnson v. Sonoco
description: In the underlying workers' compensation case, the single commissioner awarded benefits; the commission reversed; and the circuit court reinstated the single commissioner's order.  On appeal, Sonoco argued the appeal stayed the weekly payments of the award.  This Court held that the payments were not stayed and interest began to accrue following the circuit court's order.
