THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Francis Ike
      Johnson, Respondent,
				v.
				Sonoco Products
      Company and GAB Robins, Inc., Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Darlington County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26584
Heard November 19, 2008 - Filed January
  20, 2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED; AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Michael
  A. Farry and David A. Wilson, both of Horton, Drawdy, Ward & Jenkins, of Greenville, for Appellants.
				Vernon F. Dunbar, of Turner, Padget, Graham & Laney, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Appellants Sonoco Products Company and GAB Robins,
  Inc. (collectively, Sonoco) argue the
  circuit court erred in granting Respondent Francis Ike Johnsonâ€™s motion to
  compel payment of his workersâ€™ compensation benefits during the pendency of the
  underlying appeal.Â  We disagree and affirm.Â  We find that the circuit courtâ€™s
  award of workersâ€™ compensation benefits in the underlying appeal was not stayed
  during the appeal.Â  As a result, we conclude the circuit court retained
  authority to compel the payment of compensation benefits pursuant to Rule
  225(a), SCACR.Â  We further affirm Johnsonâ€™s entitlement to interest and related
  sanctions.Â  We modify the order of the circuit court only insofar as the
  effective date of Johnsonâ€™s entitlement to relief.Â  We remand to the circuit
  court to calculate Johnsonâ€™s entitlement to interest as of June 15, 2005, thirty
  days following entry of the circuit court order awarding Johnson benefits.
I.
The single
  commissioner awarded benefits to Johnson.Â  The commission reversed, and Johnson
  appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court reversed the commission and
  awarded benefits to Johnson.Â  Sonocoâ€™s motion to reconsider was denied, and the
  circuit court order became final on May 16, 2005.
Sonoco
  appealed to the Court of Appeals, which affirmed the judgment of the circuit
  court. Â Johnson v. Sonoco
    Products Co., Op. No. 2006-UP-281 (S.C.Ct.App. filed Sept. 20, 2006). Â Sonoco unsuccessfully sought rehearing in the Court of
  Appeals.Â  We subsequently denied Sonocoâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari.Â 
  The remittitur was sent to the lower court on June 13, 2007.
Prior
  to the conclusion of the underlying appeal, Johnson filed a motion to compel
  payment of the compensation benefits in the circuit court, together with a
  subsequent motion in the circuit court for sanctions (interest and a ten
  percent penalty) against Sonoco.Â  Sonoco objected to the jurisdiction of the
  circuit court on two grounds: (1) the award of workersâ€™ compensation benefits
  was stayed during the appeal, and (2) absent a remand from the appellate court,
  the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to consider Johnsonâ€™s motions.Â  The
  circuit court rejected Sonocoâ€™s arguments and awarded relief, calculating
  Johnsonâ€™s entitlement to interest as of the date of the single commissionerâ€™s
  order, May 29, 2002, and assessing a ten percent penalty.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s
  initial order granting relief was filed December 20, 2006, and an amended order
  was filed on March 6, 2007, following Sonocoâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â 
  Sonoco appealed.Â  Thereafter, as noted above, the underlying appeal became
  final and the remittitur was sent to the lower court.
Following
  the circuit court order of March 6, 2007, Sonoco paid Johnson his compensation
  benefits, but continued with the current appeal challenging the award of
  interest and ten percent penalty.Â  The appeal is before us pursuant to Rule
  204(b), SCACR, certification.
II.
The
  first issue we must resolve is whether the appeal in the underlying case stayed
  Sonocoâ€™s responsibility to make weekly compensation payments to Johnson.Â  Rule
  225(a), SCACR, provides the general rule that service of a notice of appeal in
  a civil matter automatically stays matters affected by the appeal.Â  Some of the
  exceptions to this rule are found in Rule 225(b), which sets forth a non-exhaustive
  list.Â  Rule 225 expressly provides that exceptions to the general rule extend
  beyond the list in subsection (b) and are found in statutes, court rules, and
  case law.
This Court provided
  such case law when it previously addressed this issue of whether an award of
  workersâ€™ compensation benefits by the circuit court would be stayed by the
  service of the notice of appeal in Case v. Hermitage Cotton Mills, 236
  S.C. 515, 534, 115 S.E.2d 57, 67-68 (1960).Â  In Hermitage this Court
  stated:

	[I]f the
  Commission should deny him compensation and upon his appeal the circuit court
  should reverse the Commission and hold his claim compensable, the weekly payments
  to be made by the employer pending determination of an appeal from that
  judgment to the Supreme Court should commence from the
  date of the circuit courtâ€™s judgment and should not be calculated retroactively
  from the date of the Commissionâ€™s decision.

Id.Â  In making this determination, this Court interpreted
  section 72-356 of the South Carolina Code (1952).Â  Hermitage, 236 S.C.
  at 534, 115 S.E.2d at 67.Â  This section is substantially similar to section
  42-17-60 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007).Â  We hold that the rule in Hermitage is on point.Â  Therefore, when the commissionâ€™s denial of benefits is reversed
  and the award is made by the circuit court, the weekly payments are not stayed
  by the appeal.[1]
We further note
  that we have already made such a ruling in this case.Â  In an order
  issued by this Court on November 14, 2006, this Court granted Sonocoâ€™s motion
  for an extension of time to file its petition for certiorari, and we
  specifically stated that the award of benefits to Johnson â€œis not stayed by the
  pendency of this matter.â€Â  This Court went on to cite section 42-17-60; Rule
  225, SCACR; Hermitage, 236 S.C. 515, 115 S.E.2d 57; and McLeod v.
    Piggly Wiggly Carolina Co., 280 S.C. 466, 313 S.E.2d 38 (Ct. App. 1984).
We next turn to the
  authority of the circuit court to compel, in the absence of a remand order, the
  weekly payments during the pendency of the appeal.Â  The answer is unambiguously
  provided in Rule 225(a), SCACR, which states, â€œ[t]he lower court . . . retains
  jurisdiction over matters not affected by the appeal including the authority
    to enforce matters not stayed by the appeal.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The
  circuit court retained authority to compel the payment of weekly benefits, and
  Sonocoâ€™s arguments to the contrary are without merit.Â  No remand from the
  appellate court was necessary.Â  Moreover, because the awards of interest and
  penalty are inextricably linked to Sonocoâ€™s nonpayment of benefits, we follow
  the rationale of Hermitage and hold that the matters
  of interest and penalty were not stayed by the appeal.
Sonoco
  further challenges the authority of the circuit court to award interest and assess
  the ten percent penalty under section 42-9-90 of the South Carolina Code (1976).Â  Sonoco contends such an
  award rests exclusively in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  We find this
  issue is not preserved.Â  The issue first appears in Sonocoâ€™s motion seeking
  reconsideration of the circuit courtâ€™s December 20, 2006 order.Â  An issue may
  not be raised for the first time in a motion to reconsider. Â Commercial
    Credit Loans, Inc. v. Riddle, 334 S.C. 176, 186, 512 S.E.2d 123, 129 (Ct.
  App. 1999) (â€œFurther, because the transcript of the proceedings below is
  omitted from the record, it appears the first time Commercial Credit made this
  argument was in its Rule 59(e) motion for reconsideration. Â Accordingly, this
  issue is not properly preserved for our review.â€). Â The matters of interest and
  the ten percent penalty were squarely before the circuit court, and Sonocoâ€™s
  pre-hearing written responses to Johnsonâ€™s motions did not raise the section
  42-9-90 challenge.Â  Moreover, the transcript of the hearing in the circuit
  court is not included in the record on appeal. Â Medlock v. One 1985 Jeep
    Cherokee VIN 1JCWB7828FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 132, 470 S.E.2d 373, 376
  (1996) (â€œThe appellant has the burden of providing this court with a sufficient
  record upon which to make a decision.â€); Smith v. Ridgeway Chemicals, Inc.,
  302 S.C. 303, 306, 395 S.E.2d 742, 744 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œIt is incumbent upon
  an appellant to present a record sufficient to permit a review of a trial
  judgeâ€™s rulings.â€).Â  We therefore affirm the awards of interest and ten percent
  penalty.Â  Johnson is additionally entitled to interest on the ten percent
  penalty.
We do agree with Sonocoâ€™s final assignment of error that Johnson
  is not entitled to interest from the date of the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  We
  are guided by the reasoning of Hermitage.Â  236 S.C. at 534, 115 S.E.2d at 67-68 (â€œ[U]pon his
  appeal [if] the circuit court should reverse the Commission and hold his claim
  compensable, the weekly payments to be made by the employer pending
  determination of an appeal from that judgment to the Supreme Court should
  commence from the date of the circuit courtâ€™s judgment and should not be
  calculated retroactively from the date of the Commissionâ€™s decision.â€).Â  This Court
  in Hermitage cited to section 72-356 of the South Carolina Code (1952)
  in referencing a thirty-day supersedeas on appeals from an award of benefits.Â  Id.
Section
  72-356 is the predecessor to section 42-17-60 of the
  South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007).Â  The thirty-day time period for appeals
  remains a part of section 42-17-60, with the provision that â€œafter that time, the employer is required to make weekly payments
  of compensation and to provide medical treatment ordered . . . .â€Â  Because the
  commission denied Johnsonâ€™s claim and the circuit court awarded benefits, we apply
  this statutory thirty-day supersedeas following the entry of the circuit court
  order, after which the compensation payments should have been made.Â  There was
  no legitimate reason to justify or excuse Sonocoâ€™s failure to pay compensation
  benefits to Johnson during the pendency of the underlying appeal.Â  Johnson is therefore entitled to an award of interest calculated
  from June 15, 2005, which is thirty days from the award of benefits in the circuit
  court.Â  We remand to the circuit court for the sole purpose of calculating the
  interest due Johnson.
III.
The
  award of workersâ€™ compensation benefits by the circuit court was not stayed by
  the appeal.Â  Pursuant to Rule 225(a), the circuit court had jurisdiction to
  compel the payment of benefits, as well as interest and penalty, during the
  pendency of the appeal.Â  We affirm the circuit court in its entirety, save the
  effective date of the award of interest.Â  The matter is remanded to the circuit
  court to calculate the award of interest calculated from June 15, 2005.[2]

AFFIRMED
  AS MODIFIED; AND REMANDED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, BEATTY, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore,
  concur.


[1]  We
  recognize the procedure followed in this case has been statutorily modified.Â 
  For injuries occurring on or after July 1, 2007, appeals from the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commission go directly from the commission to the Court of
  Appeals.Â  See Act 111, 2007 S.C. Acts 111.
[2]  The
  principle payment of the ten percent penalty ($20,513) should be made
  promptly.Â  Moreover, the parties can compute the amount of interest due
  Johnson, and we urge the parties, through counsel, to do so and bring this unreasonably
  protracted litigation to an end.Â  The circuit court should not be further
  burdened with this unnecessary litigation.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Carlyle McGill, Appellant,
				v.
				Tracy Moore,
      Rufus Alton Moore, Pearline Hutto, Estate of Bennie Moore, believed to be the
      above/below named persons, known or unknown, claiming thereunder, being named
      herein Jane Doe and Richard Roe, Estate of Vernice Alexander, believed to be
      William Alexander, Grady Alexander, and any and all persons, known or
      unknown, claiming under both Alexander estates, collectively known as Jane
      Doe and Richard Roe, Respondents.
				_________________________
				Tracy
      Moore, Rufus Alton Moore and Pearline Hutto, and Estate of Iola Moore Smith,
      Edward J. Smith, Jr., Newana Smith Barnes, Counter-Plaintiffs,
				v.
				Carlyle McGill, Estate of Lawrence Moore, Estate 
				of Vernice Moore Alexander, the heirs or which are believed to 
				be William Alexander, Estate of Grady Alexander, Jr., Leonard 
				Alexander, and Estate of John Stanley Alexander, Estate of Grady 
				Alexander, Jr., the heirs of which are believed to be Rava A. 
				Colby, Richard L. Alexander, and Regina Alexander, Estate of 
				John Stanley Alexander, the heirs of which are believed to be 
				Tanisha Alexander, and Tora Alexander, Estate of Otis Moore, 
				Tracy Moore, Estate of Alberta Moore Feemster, Estate of Bennie 
				Lewis Moore, John Doe, a fictitious person representing the 
				class of all unknown adult, mentally competent, unimprisoned, 
				non-military persons, who claim any right, title, or interest 
				in, or lien upon, the real estate described in the Counterclaim 
				herein; and Richard Roe, another fictitious person representing 
				the class of all unknown persons who are either: under the age 
				of eighteen (18) years, imprisoned, or in the Armed Forces, and who
      claim any right, title or interest in, or lien upon, the real estate
      described in the Counterclaim herein, which fictitious person includes but
      are not limited to, all unknown heirs at law, distributees, devisees or
      assigns of any deceased heirs of the following persons including, but not
      limited to, Lawrence Moore, Vernice Moore Alexander, Grady Alexander, Jr.,
      John Stanley Alexander, Otis Moore, Alberta Moore Feemster, and Bennie Lewis
      Moore, and all persons entitled to claim under or through them, or any of
      them, Counter-Defendants.
			
		
	

Appeal from York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball III, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26585
Heard November 18, 2008 - Filed January
  20, 2009Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Brian
  Scott McCoy, of Horack Talley, of Rock Hill, and William M. Brice III, of Brice
  Law Firm, of York, for Appellant.
				John
  Martin Foster, of Rock Hill, for Respondents.
				Paula
  Knox Brown, of Rock Hill, for Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, Appellant Carlyle McGill filed suit against
  Respondents seeking specific performance on three contracts for the sale of
  land.Â  The master-in-equity ruled in favor of Respondents, finding that the
  contracts contained a condition precedent which had not been satisfied.Â  We
  affirm.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background

Respondents
  are owners of undivided interests of a tract of land near Hickory Grove, South Carolina by way of intestate succession and devises from wills.Â  Appellant owns a
  tract of land adjacent to Respondentsâ€™ property.Â  Although Appellant was aware
  that many of the owners did not live in the area and that some owners were
  unknown, he approached Respondent Tracy Moore regarding a possible offer to
  purchase the land, and in 2000, Appellantâ€™s attorney drafted a â€œContract for Sale.â€ The contract provided:

	4.     PRICE:Â  The Purchase Price is
  $1,000.00 per acre, with final purchase price being based on the acreage shown
  on new survey.Â  All heirs of Rufus Alton Moore hereby agree that his or her
  share of the purchase price will be in accordance with their individual
  percentage of ownership as determined by the probate of the Estate . . . 
	5.     CLOSING:Â  Closing shall be held on
  or before thirty (30) days from the date the last contract is signed or if not
  possible by that date, then the parties hereto agree to an extension time of
  thirty (30) days.

Appellant
  presented nine identical contracts to various owners, of which eight owners
  signed.[1]Â 
  Of the eight signed contracts, five were closed and Appellant received deeds
  representing the interests of those owners.Â  The remaining three were never
  closed.Â  After Appellantâ€™s repeated requests to close the three contracts
  failed, Appellant filed suit seeking specific performance.Â  Respondents filed a
  counterclaim seeking partition or sale of the property and moved to allow
  certain owners not named in the original complaint to intervene.Â  The master
  granted the motion to intervene and appointed a guardian ad litem to
  represent the interests of any incompetent person or person under the age of
  eighteen who may have had a claim to any interest in the property.Â  
At
  trial, Appellant and Appellantâ€™s wife testified.Â  Respondents, however, argued
  that contract interpretation was a question of law and did not present any
  evidence.Â  The master found that the
  language in the contract created a condition precedent requiring all owners to
  sign a contract before the closing could take place.Â  Therefore, because one of
  the contracts was never signed, the master ruled Appellant was not entitled to
  specific performance. 

Appellant
  appealed the masterâ€™s order, and this Court certified the case pursuant to Rule
  204(b), SCACR.[2]Â 
  Appellant presents the following issues for review:

	
		
			I.
			Did the master err in holding that
  the language of the contracts created a condition precedent?
 
		
		
			II.
			If the contract set forth a
  condition precedent, are Respondents permitted to enforce such a condition
  since the condition would have been for the benefit of Appellant?
 
		
		
			III.
			Did the master err in denying
  specific performance because Appellant substantially complied with any
  condition of unity?
 
		
		
			IV.
			Did the master err in excluding
  testimony regarding the intent of the parties?
		
	

Standard of Review
An action to construe
  a contract is an action at law.Â  Pruitt
    v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 343 S.C. 335, 339, 540 S.E.2d 843,
  845 (2001).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s
  findings of fact will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidence
  which reasonably supports the courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stanley v. Atlantic Title Ins. Co., 377
  S.C. 405, 409, 661 S.E.2d 62, 64 (2008).

Law/Analysis
I. Condition Precedent
Appellant argues that the master erred in finding that
  the contract contained a condition precedent.Â  We disagree.
The cardinal rule of contract interpretation is to ascertain and
  give legal effect to the partiesâ€™ intentions as determined by the contract
  language.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire and Cas. Co., 353
  S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â 
  Where the contractâ€™s language is clear and unambiguous, the language alone
  determines the contractâ€™s force and effect.Â  Schulmeyer, 353 S.C. at
  495, 579 S.E.2d at 134.Â  A contract
  is read as a whole document so that one may not create an ambiguity by pointing out
  a single sentence or clause.Â  Id.Â  It is a question of law for the court whether the
  language of a contract is ambiguous.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 623,
  550 S.E.2d 299, 302-03 (2001).Â  
We hold that the master correctly found that the contracts
  contained a condition precedent that all owners sign the contract agreeing to
  sell their interests before any contract could be enforced.Â  Reading all of the
  provisions as a whole, we find that the contract assumes that all owners would sell
  their interests in the property and that Appellant would subsequently be the
  sole owner of the property.Â  For example, the contract provides that â€œall
  heirsâ€ agree to a certain purchase price and that closing would be held after
  â€œthe last contractâ€ was signed.Â  The language used in the contract indicates
  that the parties contemplated that the closing would not take place until all
  owners agreed to the terms of the contract, and thus, Appellant could not
  enforce the contract against any owner until all owners signed a contract.Â  
Appellant argues that the primary purpose of the contract was for
  the purchase of individual interests in the property and that â€œfrom the date
  the last contract is signedâ€ relates only to the timing of the closing.Â  In our
  view, Appellant impermissibly focuses on one provision in order to create an
  ambiguity and ignores the rest of the language in the contract indicating that
  the contract required unity of all owners before closing would take place.Â  See Schulmeyer, 353
  S.C. at 495, 579 S.E.2d at 134 (recognizing that the meaning of a
  particular word or phrase is not determined by considering the word or phrase
  by itself, but by reading the contract as a whole and considering the context
  and subject matter of the contract).Â  However, even if the contract was
  ambiguous, any ambiguity will be construed in favor of Respondents as the
  non-drafting party.Â  See S. Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v.
    Middleton, 356 S.C. 444, 447, 590 S.E.2d 27,
  29 (2003) (holding that ambiguous language
  in a contract should be interpreted strongly in favor of the non-drafting
  party).Â  
Had Appellant intended to purchase the interests of an individual
  owner without regard to the other ownersâ€™ interest, he could have easily drafted
  a contract to reflect this intent.Â  In our view, to construe the contract
  according to Appellantâ€™s interpretation would not be faithful to the entire
  document and would not reflect the partiesâ€™ intentions.Â  Accordingly, we hold
  that the contract contained a condition precedent which was not satisfied.Â  
II.
  Respondentsâ€™ Ability to Enforce the Condition Precedent
Appellant
  argues that even if the contract contained a condition precedent requiring all
  owners to sign the contract, this condition would have been for the benefit of
  Appellant, which he could waive and which could not be enforced by
  Respondents.Â  We disagree.
In Ehlke v. Nemec Const. Co., Inc., the court of appeals held that where a condition precedent was
  solely for the benefit of one party, it could not be asserted as a forfeiture
  by the other party.Â  298 S.C. 477, 381 S.E.2d 508 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  In this case,
  however, Appellant cannot show the condition was solely for his benefit.Â 
  Rather, the condition was in accordance with the partiesâ€™ intent
  that the contract would be enforceable once all of the owners had signed the
  contract.Â  See id. at 480, 381 S.E.2d at 511 (finding that the
  intention of the parties as deduced from the language used, the surrounding
  circumstances at the time the contract was executed, and the purpose sought to
  be accomplished by the insertion of the provisionâ€ was that parties intended
  that the condition precedent was for the benefit of the plaintiff).Â  Again, if
  the parties intended for this condition to be solely for Appellantâ€™s benefit,
  Appellant could have easily drafted language reflecting this intent.Â  
III.
  Substantial Compliance
Appellant argues that even if the contract contained a condition
  precedent requiring all owners to sign the contract, he substantially complied
  with this condition because eight of the nine contracts distributed were
  signed.Â  We disagree.
If a
  contract contains a condition precedent, that condition must either occur or it
  must be excused before a partyâ€™s duty to perform arises.Â  See Worley v. Yarborough Ford, Inc., 317 S.C. 206, 210, 452 S.E.2d
  622, 624 (Ct. App. 1994) (recognizing that a
  condition precedent is a fact
  other than the lapse of time,
  which, unless excused, must exist or occur before a duty of immediate performance arises).Â  In this case, before the closing could occur, the contract required all of the
  owners to sign the contract.Â  This condition has not been met and has not been
  excused.Â  Therefore, we hold that Appellant may not circumvent the contractâ€™s
  condition precedent by arguing substantial compliance.[3]Â Â  
IV. Testimony
Appellant argues that the master erred in excluding his testimony
  regarding the intent of the parties in using specific terms in the contract
  such as â€œall heirsâ€ and â€œclosing.â€Â  We disagree.
The parol evidence rule prevents the introduction of extrinsic
  evidence of agreements or understandings contemporaneous with or prior to execution
  of a written instrument when the extrinsic evidence is to be used to
  contradict, vary or explain the written instrument.Â  In re Estate
    of Holden, 343 S.C. 267, 275-76, 539 S.E.2d
  703, 708 (2000).Â  Where a written
  instrument is unambiguous, parol evidence is inadmissible to ascertain the true
  intent and meaning of the parties.Â  Id.
We
  hold that the master properly excluded this testimony. Â The terms in the
  contract are unambiguous and Appellant was therefore barred from introducing
  evidence to explain these terms.Â  See Silver v. Aabstract Pools & Spas, Inc., 376 S.C. 585, 591, 658 S.E.2d 539, 542 (Ct.
  App. 2008), quoting McPherson v. J.E. Sirrine & Co., 206 S.C. 183,
  204, 33 S.E.2d 501, 509 (1945) (â€œIn construing and determining the effect of a
  written contract, the intention of the parties and the
  meaning are gathered primarily from . . . the four corners of the instrumentâ€).
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the master correctly
  denied Appellant specific performance relief.Â  
WALLER, BEATTY, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore,
  concur.


[1] Owner Iola Moore Smith was unable to sign the contract because she was
  incompetent, and before family members could obtain a power of attorney, she
  passed away.Â  
[2] Respondents and the guardian ad litem argue that we should dismiss this
  appeal because Appellant failed to serve the notice of appeal on the guardian ad
    litem pursuant to Rule 203, SCACR.Â  We find Appellant was not required to
  serve the notice of appeal upon the guardian ad litem because this
  appeal does not involve the partition action and thus, the guardian ad litem is
  not an â€œadverse partyâ€ in this appeal and not a â€œrespondent.â€Â  
[3] This argument appears to be an estoppel claim.Â  However, any
  estoppel issues are not preserved for review as Appellant did not raise the
  issue of estoppel before the master and has not explicitly raised it to this
  Court.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Dorothy
      Windham, Respondent,
				v.
				Donald Allen
      Riddle and Jennifer D. Riddle, Petitioners.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Orangeburg County
OlinÂ  D.Â  Burgdorf, Master-in-Equity
Opinion No. 26586
Heard October 7, 2008 - Filed January 20,
  2009 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Pete Kulmala, of Harvey & Kulmala, of Barnwell, for Petitioners.
				Clinch H. Belser, Jr. and Michael J. Polk, of Belser & Belser
  PA, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this declaratory judgment
  action brought by Dorothy Windham, the master-in-equity found Donald and
  Jennifer Riddle (the Riddles) have an appurtenant easement for access and irrigation
  purposes across Windhamâ€™s property.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed the master-in-equityâ€™s
  holding.Â  Windham v. Riddle, 370 S.C. 415, 635 S.E.2d 558 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  This Court granted the Riddlesâ€™ petition for a writ of certiorari to
  review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The
  Riddles and Windham are adjacent property owners in Orangeburg County. Â Both parties purchased their property from a common grantor, Danny Covington.Â  Covington purchased the combined property in 1991 from Edisto Farm Credit.Â  Marvin Davis,
  the previous owner, had used the property as a dairy farm. Â In 1992, Covington had the property surveyed and divided into two tracts, 1-A and 1-B.Â  
On November 15,
  1992, Covington and Windham entered into a contract of sale for the
  approximately 142.38 acre tract 1-B (the Windham tract).Â  Pursuant to the terms
  of the contract, Windham agreed to purchase the tract in monthly installments
  over a ten-year period but was allowed to pre-pay the balance without penalty.Â 
  During the period of these payments, Windham was allowed full possession and
  occupancy of the property.Â  After Windham satisfied the purchase price, Covington agreed to deliver â€œgood and marketable titleâ€ to Windham.Â  In addition to these
  terms, the contract provided in part:

	Seller
  to have a 50′ easement of ingress and egress for the purpose of operating
  and maintaining an irrigation system.Â  [S]aid easement to be centered over
  existing underground piping.Â  Seller agrees not to pump pond lower than 4′
  below full stage.Â  Existing overhead utilities easement to remain as is.Â  When
  possible seller to run system at times convenient to buyer.Â  Buyer not
  restricting use more than 36 hours at a given time.Â  Seller to have all rights
  to use waters in pond.Â  Seller and buyer mutually agree to use pond dam and canal
  as an easement.Â  [S]eller providing buyer 25′ easement for ingress and
  egress to canal through existing woods road. 

After entering into the
  contract of sale, Windham and her family used the tract as a family retreat,
  and they visited every other weekend.Â  Covington continued to farm on tract 1-A.Â  
In June of 1993, Covington leased a portion of the 257.49 acre tract 1-A (the Riddle tract) to the Riddles,
  who began using the land to operate a dairy farm. Â In the spring of 1994, Covington and the Riddles installed an aboveground irrigation system over the existing
  underground piping on the Windham tract.Â  The pumping station for the
  irrigation system is located on the pond that Windham owns and transports water
  to the Riddle tract.Â  Access to the pump is controlled by a locked gate on the Windham tract.
On November 17,
  1997, Covington conveyed tract 1-A in its entirety to the Riddles.Â  The deed
  provided in pertinent part:

	Said
  conveyance is subject to a 30-foot easement, a 50-foot irrigation easement, a
  25-foot access easement along existing woods road and a canal, all as set forth
  and shown on the above-referenced plat.Â  

On
  December 15, 1998, pursuant to the installment contract, Covington deeded the
  tract to Windham after she paid off the purchase price.Â  The deed stated in
  relevant part:

	Said
  conveyance is subject to a (fifty) 50 foot easement of ingress and egress for
  the purpose of operating and maintaining an irrigation system and an agreement
  as to the use of said irrigation easement and irrigation system as set forth in
  that certain Contract of Sale by and between Danny Covington a/k/a J. Danny
  Covington, as Seller and Dorothy Windham, as Buyer dated November 15, 1992 and
  recorded in the office the Register of Deeds for Orangeburg County on December
  28, 1992 . . . . 

Although Windham initially allowed the Riddles to use the pond for irrigation purposes, she brought
  an action for declaratory judgment and injunctive relief against the Riddles on
  November 12, 2003, claiming the Riddles exceeded the use of the easement as
  contemplated by Covington and Windham in the contract of sale.Â  In her
  Complaint, Windham specifically alleged the Riddles:Â  allowed their livestock
  to roam on Windhamâ€™s property; destroyed Windhamâ€™s fences, gates, and security
  devices; operated the irrigation system for excessive periods of time which
  created a nuisance; obtained waters from Windhamâ€™s property without any legal
  right; and allowed third parties access to the Windham property for
  â€œunauthorized purposes.â€ Â As the basis for her action, Windham asserted the
  easement created in the contract of sale and resulting deed was an easement in
  gross and, thus, the Riddles had no right to this easement.Â  In response, the
  Riddles asserted Windham was estopped from denying the validity of the
  easement. Â The Riddles also claimed the easement was appurtenant to the Riddle
  tract.Â  
After a trial, the
  master-in-equity found that the contract of sale between Windham and Covington, in conjunction with the Windham and Riddle deeds, established â€œvarious
  easements for the purpose of irrigating Tract 1-A, the Riddle property.â€Â  The
  master further held the easements were appurtenant to the Riddle tract and,
  therefore, passed to the Riddles when Covington conveyed the land to them.Â 
  Additionally, the master concluded that Windham could not maintain an action
  for trespass because the Riddles, the owners of the dominant estate, did not
  abuse or exceed the limits of the easements.Â  Ultimately, the master dismissed Windhamâ€™s Complaint with prejudice and ordered that the â€œirrigation easements are
  appurtenant to the real estate subject to this action and exist as set forth on
  the recorded plats.â€Â  
Subsequently, the
  master denied Windhamâ€™s motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  Windham then appealed the masterâ€™s decision to the Court of Appeals. 
In a divided
  opinion, the Court of Appeals reversed the decision of the master-in-equity.Â  Windham v. Riddle, 370 S.C. 415, 635 S.E.2d 558 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The
  majority found the master erred by concluding that the easement at issue was
  appurtenant rather than in gross.Â  Prefacing its analysis with a general
  discussion of the differences between an appurtenant easement and an easement
  in gross, the majority focused on the installment land contract that was the
  subject of the dispute.Â  Citing this Courtâ€™s opinion in Lewis v. Premium
    Investment Corporation, the majority noted that typically in this type of
  contract, â€œthe seller retains legal title until the purchase price has been
  fully paid, and the purchaser is entitled to immediate possession.â€Â  Id. at 419, 635 S.E.2d at 560; see Lewis v. Premium Inv. Corp., 351
  S.C. 167, 170-73, 568 S.E.2d 361, 363-64 (2002) (stating that in an installment
  land contract, the seller retains legal title until the purchase price is fully
  paid and that the vendee in possession of the land is the owner of an equitable
  interest in the property).Â  
Relying
  on the long-standing common law rule that an easement cannot exist where both
  the purported servient and dominant estates are owned by the same person, the
  majority found that an easement could not have been created by the 1992 contract
  of sale.Â  Id. at 419, 635 S.E.2d at 560 (citing Haselden v. Schein,
  167 S.C. 534, 539, 166 S.E. 634, 635 (1932)).Â  Specifically, the majority
  stated, â€œ[a]s Covington retained legal title to the Windham tract and also held
  title to the Riddle tract, no easement could have been created by the Windham contract of sale in 1992.â€Â  Windham, 370 S.C. at 419, 635 S.E.2d at 560.Â Â  
The majority further
  relied on its earlier decision in Springob v. Farrar, 334 S.C. 585, 514
  S.E.2d 135 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In Springob, Dr. Shenoy owned Lot 14, and
  his wife owned adjoining Lot 13, where the Shenoysâ€™ home was located.Â  The
  Shenoys built a well on Lot 14 and attached it to an irrigation system serving Lot 13.Â  In 1986, Dr. Shenoy sold Lot 14 to L.G.B., Inc.Â  The deed from Dr. Shenoy
  â€œreserved to the Grantorâ€ an easement on Lot 13 for use of the well on Lot 14.Â  A house was built on Lot 14 and eventually the Farrars bought the property in
  1988.Â  The deed to the Farrars stated â€œthis conveyance is subject to all
  easements, rights, reservations, restrictions, and covenants of record
  affecting said property.â€ Â Id. at 587, 514 S.E.2d at 137.Â  The Farrarsâ€™
  closing attorney informed them of the easement to the well located on their
  property.Â  In 1989, Mrs. Shenoy sold Lot 13 to Kenneth Perry, and the South
  Carolina Federal Savings Bank obtained title to the lot through foreclosure.Â 
  While Lot 13 was vacant, the Farrars disconnected the well on their property
  from the Lot 13 irrigation system and connected it to their own system serving Lot 14.Â  
In 1993, Springob
  purchased Lot 13 unaware of the easement on Lot 14.Â  After discovering the well
  on Lot 14, Springob demanded use of the well, but the Farrars refused.Â 
  Springob brought an action for trespass and intentional interference with and
  obstruction of an easement.Â  He also sought an injunction prohibiting the Farrars
  from further interfering with the easement.Â  The Farrars answered, asserting
  the easement was personal to Dr. Shenoy and, therefore, was an easement in
  gross.Â  The Court of Appeals agreed with the Farrars, finding the easement was
  in gross rather than appurtenant.Â  In so holding, the Court of Appeals stated:

	In
  this case, L.G.B. Deed reserved an easement in favor of â€œthe Grantor.â€Â  The
  grantor of the L.G.B. Deed was Dr. Shenoy, the sole owner of Lot 14.Â  Because
  the easement was reserved for Dr. Shenoy only, and Dr. Shenoy did not own Lot 13, the lot benefited by the easement, the requirement that an appurtenant easement
  have â€œone terminus on the land of the party claiming itâ€ is not satisfied.

Id. at 589, 514 S.E.2d at 137-38.Â  
Because
  the Windham deed referred to the language of the contract of sale, which
  reserved an easement in favor of â€œSellerâ€ only, and Covington no longer owned
  the Riddle tract at the time he deeded the Windham tract, the majority further
  found an appurtenant easement was not created for the benefit of the Riddles as
  in Springob.Â  Windham, 370 S.C. at 419-20, 635 S.E.2d at 560-61.Â  
In
  contrast, the dissent found that an appurtenant easement was established in the
  contract for the sale of the land from Covington to Windham. Â Id. at 421-22,
  635 S.E.2d at 561. Â In reaching this conclusion, the dissent focused on when
  the easement was created and distinguished the instant case from Haselden and Springob.Â  The dissent believed that the contract of sale between Windham and Covington, rather than the deed, was â€œthe instrument that established the
  legal relationship between the partiesâ€ and was â€œthe functional equivalent of a
  conveyance coupled with a method of financing.â€Â  Id. at 422, 635 S.E.2d
  at 561.Â  
Although
  the dissent believed that â€œno discussion of the requirement that an appurtenant
  easement have one terminus on the land of the party claimingâ€ was necessary,
  the dissent felt compelled to distinguish Springob because the majority
  heavily relied on that decision.Â  Id. at 423, 635 S.E.2d at 562.Â Â Â  Â 
In
  distinguishing that case, the dissent noted that in Springob, the person
  who reserved the easement never owned the purported dominant estate, only
  owning at one time the servient estate.Â  In contrast, Covington â€œunquestionably
  owned the dominant estate at the time the contract was entered into.â€Â  Id. at 423, 635 S.E.2d at 562.Â  Secondly, the dissent did not find dispositive the
  fact that the Riddle deed did not create an appurtenant easement.Â  The dissent
  reasoned that â€œthere is no necessity to expressly mention an easement
  appurtenant when conveying the dominant estate.â€ Id. Â Because â€œall the
  elements necessary for the creation of an easement appurtenant were in
  existence at the time the contract was entered into between Covington and
  Windham,â€ the dissent concluded that the later conveyance of â€œâ€˜bare legal titleâ€™
  was a required fulfillment of the contractual terms already set in stone.â€Â  Id. at 423-24, 635 S.E.2d at 562. 
The Riddles
  petitioned for and were granted a writ of certiorari for this Court to review
  the decision of the Court of Appeals.Â  
DISCUSSION
The
  Riddles assert the Court of Appeals erred in holding that the easement created
  through the sales of two parcels by Covington, a common grantor, was an
  easement in gross rather than an appurtenant easement.Â  Relying primarily on the
  dissent, the Riddles claim that under the majorityâ€™s analysis â€œthe nature of
  this transaction [an installment land contract] erects an insurmountable
  obstacle to the easementâ€™s being recognized as appurtenant.â€Â  Although the
  Riddles do not dispute that Covington retained â€œtitle ownershipâ€ of the
  servient estate after the 1992 sale to Windham, they contend the sales contract
  conveyed to Windham the most significant rights in the property.Â  Thus, the
  Riddlesâ€™ right of access â€œwas described and reserved in the 1992 sales
  agreement.â€Â  As will be discussed, we agree with the majority opinion in the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ decision and specifically reject the reasoning in the
  dissenting opinion.
â€œAn easement is a right which one person
  has to use the land of another for a specific purpose, and gives no title to
  the land on which the servitude is imposed.â€ Douglas v. Med. Investors, Inc.,
  256 S.C. 440, 445, 182 S.E.2d 720, 722 (1971) (citations omitted).Â  â€œAn
  easement is therefore not an estate in lands in the usual sense.â€ Id.Â  An easement may be created by reservation in a deed. Â Sandy Island Corp. v.
    Ragsdale, 246 S.C. 414, 419, 143 S.E.2d 803, 806 (1965).Â  
In construing a deed, â€œthe intention of the grantor must be ascertained and
  effectuated, unless that intention contravenes some well settled rule of law or
  public policy.â€ Â Wayburn v. Smith, 270 S.C. 38, 41-42, 239 S.E.2d 890,
  892 (1977).Â  â€œIn determining the grantorâ€™s intent, the deed must be construed as a whole and effect given to every part if it
  can be done consistently with the law.â€ Gardner v. Mozingo, 293
  S.C. 23, 25, 358 S.E.2d 390, 391-92 (1987). Â â€œThe intention of the grantor must
  be found within the four corners of the deed.â€ Id. 
In Tupper v. Dorchester County, this Court
  distinguished between the types of easements, stating:

	The character of an express easement is
  determined by the nature of the right and the intention of the parties creating
  it. 25 Am. Jur. 2d Easements and Licenses Â§ 13 (1966).Â  An easement in
  gross is a mere personal privilege to use the land of another; the privilege is
  incapable of transfer. Â Sandy
    Island Corp. v. Ragsdale, 246 S.C. 414, 143 S.E.2d 803 (1965).Â  In
  contrast, an appurtenant easement inheres in the land, concerns the premises,
  has one terminus on the land of the party claiming it, and is essentially
  necessary to the enjoyment thereof. Â Id.; Smith v. Commissioners,
  312 S.C. 460, 441 S.E.2d 331 (Ct. App. 1994); Carolina Land Company, Inc. v.
    Bland, 265 S.C. 98, 217 S.E.2d 16 (1975); Sandy Island Corp. v. Ragsdale,
  supra; 12 S.C. Juris. Easements Â§ 3.Â  It also passes with the dominant
  estate upon conveyance. Â Carolina Land Co., Inc. v. Bland, supra.Â  Unless
  an easement has all the elements necessary to be an appurtenant easement, it
  will be characterized as a mere easement in gross. 12
  S.C. Juris. Easements Â§ 3(c). Where language in a plat reflecting an
  easement is capable of more than one construction, that construction which
  least restricts the property will be adopted. Â Hamilton v. CCM, Inc.,
  274 S.C. 152, 263 S.E.2d 378 (1980).

Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325-26,
  487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).
Applying the foregoing to the facts of the instant case, we agree
  with the Court of Appealsâ€™ majority opinion.Â  Under an installment land
  contract, legal title to the subject property is not transferred to the buyer
  until the purchase price is satisfied.Â  Lewis, 351 S.C. at 170-73, 568 S.E.2d at 363-64.Â 
  Therefore, pursuant to the Windham sales contract, Covington retained legal
  title to the Windham tract until 1998, when Windham paid off the purchase
  price.Â  The 1998 Windham deed stated that it was subject to the easement in
  favor of Covington, the seller, as set forth in the 1992 sales contract.Â  Because
  Covington retained legal title to both the Windham tract and the Riddle tract
  in 1992, an easement could not have been created by the 1992 installment land
  contract. Â Haselden, 167 S.C. at 539, 166 S.E. at 635.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Furthermore,
  we agree with the Court of Appeals that the 1998 Riddle deed did not create an
  appurtenant easement.Â  Before Covington conveyed legal title to Windham in 1998, he sold tract 1-A to the Riddles in 1997.Â  Given that the Windham deed reserved the easement to Covington and he sold the dominant estate to the
  Riddles in 1997, the â€œterminusâ€ requirement for an appurtenant easement was not
  met similar to the conveyance in Springob.Â  See Shia v.
    Pendergrass, 222 S.C. 342, 351, 72 S.E.2d 699, 703 (1952) (noting the
  absence of a terminus on property is fatal to claim of an appurtenant
  easement).
In
  reaching this conclusion, we have carefully considered the dissenting opinion
  in the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.[1]Â  For several reasons, we believe that an adoption of
  that approach would create
  unforeseeable ramifications in this stateâ€™s current property jurisprudence. 
First, the inherent nature of an installment land contract, an
  unrecorded document, precludes the creation of an appurtenant easement at the
  point the contract is entered into by the parties.Â  With an installment land contract, the seller retains
  legal title until the purchase price is fully paid.Â  Thus, an installment land
  contract is not, as asserted by the Riddles, tantamount to a conveyance.Â  If an
  appurtenant easement were created at the point the contract was entered into,
  problems would arise if the buyer defaulted before legal title was conveyed by
  a deed.Â  The question would then become whether the easement would be
  extinguished when the buyer defaulted or if it transferred to the next buyer.Â  Accordingly,
  we find it is essential to retain the two-part procedure of an installment land
  contract which requires not only a contract of sale but also a deed to convey
  ownership to the property after the purchase price has been satisfied.Â  Unlike
  the Riddles, we do not view these requirements as â€œtechnical,â€ but rather, find
  they serve a legitimate purpose for all parties involved in installment land
  contracts.Â  Therefore, we reject the Riddlesâ€™ contention that an appurtenant
  easement may be created simply by entering into an installment land contract.
Secondly, we believe this radical approach to appurtenant
  easements is based more on efficiency than legal analysis.Â  See John E. Lansche, Jr., Ancient, Antiquated, &
    Archaic:Â  South Carolina Fails to Embrace the Rule that a Grantor May Reserve
    and Easement in Favor of a Third Party, 52 S.C. L. Rev. 269, 285 (2000) (â€œBy overruling the common law, states
  like California and Kentucky made it easier for potential buyers conducting a
  title search to find encumbrances on a specific tract of land.Â  Under the
  common-law rule, if a grantor wanted to reserve an easement in favor of a third
  party the grantor had to execute a deed of easement to that third person.Â 
  Next, the grantor had to execute a deed to the grantee.â€).Â  Although the common
  law approach may require additional steps in creating an easement in favor of a
  third party, it is not a task that is insurmountable.Â  Therefore, we decline to
  overrule settled property law. 
Finally,
  even though this decision may appear to be inequitable, we note the Riddles are
  not without other irrigation options given their property borders the Little
  River.[2]Â 
  Thus, it is questionable whether an appurtenant easement is essentially
  necessary to the enjoyment of the property.Â  See Kershaw v. Burns,
  91 S.C. 129, 133, 74 S.E. 378, 379 (1912) (â€œThe principle is well settled that
  a right of way appurtenant cannot be granted, unless it is essentially
  necessary to the enjoyment of the land to which it appertains.â€); Ballington
    v. Paxton, 327 S.C. 372, 380, 488 S.E.2d 882, 887 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œAn
  appendant or appurtenant easement must inhere in the land, concern the
  premises, have one terminus on the land of the party claiming it, and be essentially
  necessary to the enjoyment thereof.â€). 
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we hold the Court of Appeals correctly found the Riddles do
  not have an appurtenant easement for access and irrigation purposes across Windhamâ€™s property.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in result
  only.


[1]Â  We have also reviewed the dissent in Springob and several secondary sources which have advocated for this Court to overrule
  the common law requirements for appurtenant easements.Â  These authors have
  characterized the current easement law of South Carolina to be â€œacademicâ€ and
  â€œarchaic.â€Â  According to these authors, the trend among other jurisdictions is
  to overrule the common law which would favor effectuating a grantorâ€™s intent to
  create an interest, i.e., an easement, to a third party.Â  See Springob,
  334 S.C. at 595-99, 514 S.E.2d at 141-43 (Anderson, J., dissenting) (outlining
  cases from other jurisdictions where the appellate courts rejected the common
  law rule that one cannot reserve an easement to a stranger to the title);Â  John
  E. Lansche, Jr., Ancient, Antiquated, & Archaic:Â  South Carolina Fails
    to Embrace the Rule that a Grantor May Reserve an Easement in Favor of a Third
    Party, 52 S.C. L. Rev. 269 (2000) (addressing current easement law in South
  Carolina and advocating a change in the â€œancient-common-lawâ€ principles); Michael
  A. Carbone, The Unity of Title Doctrine and Strangers to the Title:Â  A
    Slowly Dying Remnant of Ancient Common Law?, 21 QLR 597, 599-600 n.31
  (2002) (citing Springob for â€œunity of title doctrineâ€ (UTD) as
  representative of the majority rule and stating â€œ[t]he general common law rule,
  though worded differently [than UTD], is that in a deed, neither a reservation
  nor an exception in favor of a stranger to the instrument can, by force of
  ordinary words of exception or reservation, create in the stranger any title,
  right, or interest in or respecting the land conveyedâ€); see also W.W.
  Allen, Annotation, Reservation or Exception in Deed in Favor of Stranger,
  88 A.L.R.2d 1199 (1963 & Supp. 2008) (discussing â€œ[t]he broad rule grounded
  in the precedents and technicalities of common law, and which still generally
  prevails, is that in a deed neither a reservation nor an exception in favor of
  a stranger to the instrument can, by force of ordinary words of exception or
  reservation, create in the stranger any title, right, or interest in or respecting
  the land conveyedâ€).Â Â Â Â  
[2]Â  On cross-examination, Covington acknowledged that
  the Riddlesâ€™ property fronts the Little River, which is the same river from
  which they get the water for the irrigation system.Â

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of Kenneth Ray Martin, Respondent.

ORDER

The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) has filed a Petition for Interim Suspension or, in the Alternative, to Transfer Respondent to Incapacity Inactive Status1  pursuant to Rule 17, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.  In addition, ODC requests the appointment of an attorney to protect the interests of respondent’s clients pursuant to Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.  Respondent consents to being placed on incapacity inactive status. 
 IT IS ORDERED that respondent is placed on incapacity inactive status until further order of the Court.
 IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that C. Heath Ruffner, Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility for respondent’s client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain.  Mr. Ruffner shall take action as required by Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, to protect the interests of respondent’s clients.  Mr. Ruffner may make disbursements from respondent’s trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain that are necessary to effectuate this appointment.
 This Order, when served on any bank or other financial institution maintaining trust, escrow and/or operating accounts of respondent, shall serve as an injunction to prevent respondent from making withdrawals from the account(s) and shall further serve as notice to the bank or other financial institution that C. Heath Ruffner, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court.
 Finally, this Order, when served on any office of the United States Postal Service, shall serve as notice that C. Heath Ruffner, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court and has the authority to receive respondent’s mail and the authority to direct that respondent’s mail be delivered to Mr. Ruffner’s office.
 This appointment shall be for a period of no longer than nine months unless request is made to this Court for an extension. 


  
     
    s/ Costa M. Pleicones			J. 
FOR THE COURT 
  

Columbia, South Carolina
January 16, 2009

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Betty J.
          Hancock, Petitioner,
        v.
        Mid-South
          Management Co., Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Newberry County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26587
Heard November 5, 2008 - January 26, 2009Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Eugene
          C. Griffith, Jr., of Rushing & Griffith, and Samuel M. Price, Jr., both of
          Newberry, for Petitioner.
        Elizabeth
          M. Dalzell and Â Kirby D. Shealy, III, both of Baker, Ravenel & Bender, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  In Hancock v. Mid-South Management Co., Inc., the court of appeals affirmed the
  trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment in favor of Respondent Mid-South Management Company.Â  370 S.C. 131, 634 S.E.2d 12 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  We granted a writ of
  certiorari to review that decision and now reverse.
Factual/Procedural Background

Petitioner Betty J. Hancock filed a negligence action
  against Respondent after she tripped and fell in the parking lot of the office
  of The Newberry Observer, which is owned by Respondent.Â  Petitioner
  alleged Respondent was negligent in failing to maintain a safe premises.Â 
  Respondent moved for summary judgment, and at the hearing, the parties
  submitted deposition testimony from Petitioner and Petitionerâ€™s daughter-in-law
  (Daughter) and photographs of the parking lot.Â  Although Petitioner could not
  identify the exact cause of her fall, she testified that she tripped on â€œa rock
  or something to that effect,â€ â€œsomething raised up,â€ and â€œbroken asphalt.â€Â 
  Daughter, who witnessed the fall, testified that Petitioner â€œtripped on that
  mess in front of the Observer.â€Â  Additionally, Petitioner submitted an
  affidavit from a former employee who worked at the office of The Newberry
    Observer which provided that the employees were aware that the parking lot
  was in disrepair and that they had complained to management regarding the
  deteriorated state of the parking lot.Â  
The
  trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Respondent finding that the
  change in the elevation in the parking lot caused Petitionerâ€™s fall, that the
  change in elevation was not a dangerous condition, and that even if it was a
  dangerous condition, Respondent had no duty to warn since the elevation change
  was an open and obvious condition.Â  The court of appeals affirmed the trial
  courtâ€™s ruling.Â  
This
  Court granted certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision, and
  Petitioner presents the following issue for review:

  Did the
    court of appeals err in affirming the circuit courtâ€™s decision granting summary
    judgment?

Standard of Review
Summary
  judgment is appropriate where there is no genuine issue of material fact and
  it is clear the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law. Â Rule
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the
  evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Â Koester
    v. Carolina Rental Ctr., 313 S.C. 490, 493, 443 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1994).Â  
Law/Analysis
We first address
  Respondentâ€™s argument that Petitioner must present more than a mere scintilla
  of evidence to withstand a motion for summary judgment.Â  The rule followed in
  the federal court system provides that â€œa â€˜mere
  scintilla of evidenceâ€™ is not sufficient to withstand the challenge.â€ Â Rogers v. Norfolk Southern Corp., 356 S.C. 85, 92, 588 S.E.2d 87,
  90 (2003), quoting Crinkley v. Holiday Inns, 844 F.2d 156, 160 (4th Cir.1988).Â  We recognize that the court of appeals has been
  somewhat inconsistent on whether a mere scintilla of evidence will overcome a
  motion for summary judgment.[1]Â 
  This Court, however, has consistently held that where the federal standard applies or
  where a heightened burden of proof is required, there must be more than a scintilla of evidence in order to
  defeat a motion for summary judgment.[2]Â 
  Accordingly, we hold that in cases applying the
  preponderance of the evidence burden of proof, the non-moving
  party is only required to submit a mere scintilla of evidence in order to
  withstand a motion for summary judgment.Â  However, in cases requiring a
  heightened burden of proof or in cases applying federal law, we hold that the
  non-moving party must submit more than a mere scintilla of evidence to
  withstand a motion for summary judgment.[3]Â  
Turning to the merits of the case, although the operator of a parking lot is not an insurer of
  the safety of those who use the lot, reasonable care must be used by the
  operator to keep the premises used by invitees in a reasonably safe condition.Â  Henderson v. St.
    Francis Community Hosp., 303 S.C. 177, 180, 399 S.E.2d
  767, 768 (1990). Â However, a
  possessor of land is not liable to his invitees for physical harm caused to
  them by any activity or condition on the land whose danger is known or obvious
  to them, unless the possessor should anticipate the harm despite such knowledge
  or obviousness.Â  Callander v. Charleston
    Doughnut Corp., 305
  S.C. 123, 126, 406 S.E.2d 361, 362 (1991),
  adopting Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 343A, Known or Obvious Dangers (1965).
In our view, the court
  of appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment.Â 
  Petitionerâ€™s testimony, Daughterâ€™s testimony, and the former employeeâ€™s
  affidavit showed that the parking lot was in a state of disrepair.Â  Thus, taken
  in a light most favorable to Petitioner, evidence shows that Respondent knew or
  should have known that a dangerous condition existed on its premises and that
  invitees would have to encounter this condition.Â  See Henderson, 303 S.C. at 180, 399 S.E.2d at 769 (reversing the trial courtâ€™s grant of a JNOV motion because the
  plaintiff presented evidence that a hospital failed to keep its parking lot
  reasonably safe).Â  
Furthermore,
  the court of appeals erred in affirming the grant of summary judgment based on
  the finding that even if the parking lot contained a dangerous condition it was
  open and obvious.Â  While a parking lotâ€™s state of disrepair may be considered
  open and obvious, a jury could determine that Respondent should have anticipated
  that such a condition may cause an invitee to fall and injure themselves.Â Â  See Creech v.
    South Carolina Wildlife and Marine Resources Dept., 328 S.C. 24, 491 S.E.2d 571 (1997)
  (holding that a dock without a guard rail on one side was an open and obvious
  condition, but that the defendant should have anticipated the harm); Callander, 305 S.C. at 126, 406 S.E.2d at 363 (holding that although a
  missing seat on a stool was an open and obvious condition, the owner should
  have anticipated the harm).
Accordingly,
  we hold the that the court of appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s
  grant of summary judgment because a genuine issue of material facts exists
  regarding whether Petitionerâ€™s injuries resulted from a dangerous condition
  and, if so, whether Respondent should have anticipated this type of harm.Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing
  reasons, we reverse the decision of the court of appeals.
WALLER,
PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur. 


[1] In Anders v. South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins.
  Co., the court of appeals stated that â€œ[a]t the summary judgment stage of the proceedings,
  it [is] only necessary for the [nonmoving party] to submit a scintilla of
  evidence warranting determination by a jury.â€Â  307 S.C. 371, 375,
  415 S.E.2d 406, 408 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  However, the court of appeals has also declared that â€œ[t]he existence
  of a mere scintilla of evidence in support of the nonmoving partyâ€™s position is
  not sufficient to overcome a motion for summary judgment.Â  Shelton
    v. LS & K, Inc., 374 S.C. 294, 297,
  648 S.E.2d 307, 308 (Ct. App. 2007); see
    also Bravis v. Dunbar, 316 S.C. 263, 265, 449 S.E.2d
495, 496 (Ct. App.1994).Â  
[2] See Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 353
  S.C. 208, 578 S.E.2d 329 (2003) (applying the unmistakable and convincing evidence standard in an undue influence case); Whaley v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362
  S.C. 456, 609 S.E.2d 286 (2005) (applying the federal
  heightened standard in a Federal Employerâ€™s Liability Act suit); and Fleming v. Rose, 350
  S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002) (applying the clear and
convincing standard of proof in a libel action brought by a public figure).
[3] We note that this appeal does not depend on whether a mere
  scintilla of evidence is sufficient to defeat a motion for summary judgment
because Petitioner has presented more than a scintilla of evidence.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Charles R.
          Hipp, III, Respondent,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Motor Vehicles, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
Michael G. Nettles, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26588
  Heard December 4, 2008 - Filed January 26,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        General
          Counsel Frank L. Valenta, Jr., Deputy General Counsel Philip S. Porter, and Assistant
          General Counsel Linda A. Grice, all of Blythewood, for Appellant.
        Michael
          A. Timbes, of Thurmond, Kirchner & Timbes, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: South
  Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles (SCDMV) appeals the order of the circuit
  court enjoining it from suspending the driverâ€™s license of Respondent Charles
R. Hipp, III (Respondent) as a consequence of Respondentâ€™s 1993 Georgia conviction for driving under the influence (DUI).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Respondent
  was arrested and pled guilty to DUI in the State of Georgia in 1993.Â  At the
  time of the arrest, Respondent was a South Carolina resident attending college
  in South Carolina, and a driver licensed by the South Carolina Department of
  Motor Vehicles (SCDMV).Â  As a result of his plea, Respondent paid a fine to the
  State of Georgia and fulfilled other conditions required by Georgia.Â  In 2005, twelve years after his conviction, Respondent received notice from the
  SCDMV that his South Carolina driverâ€™s license was being suspended as a
  consequence of his 1993 Georgia DUI conviction.Â  Respondent filed a declaratory
  judgment action asking the court to enjoin suspension of his license.Â  The
  circuit court issued an order enjoining the SCDMV from suspending Respondentâ€™s
  driverâ€™s license.
ISSUE
Did
  the circuit court err in enjoining the suspension of Respondentâ€™s driverâ€™s
  license?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œActions for injunctive relief are equitable in
  nature.â€ Shaw v. Coleman, 373 S.C. 485, 492, 645 S.E.2d 252, 256 (Ct.
  App. 2007).Â  In actions in equity this Court may find facts in accordance with
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Id.
ANALYSIS
The circuit court cited three grounds for enjoining
  suspension of Respondentâ€™s driverâ€™s license: (1) that the applicable statute is
  ambiguous; (2) the doctrine of laches; and (3) that suspension twelve years
  after conviction violates the â€œfundamental fairnessâ€ required by due process.Â 
  We find the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion as to fundamental fairness to be
  persuasive and so, affirm.[1]
A
  personâ€™s interest in his driverâ€™s license is property that a state may not take
  away without satisfying the requirements of due process. Bell v.
    Burson, 402 U.S. 535, 91 S.Ct. 1586, 29 L.Ed2d 90 (1971).Â Â  Due process is
  violated when a party is denied fundamental fairness. City of Spartanburg v. Parris, 251 S.C. 187, 191, 161 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1968).Â  
This Court addressed facts similar to those in the case at hand in State v. Chavis, 261 S.C. 408, 200 S.E.2d 390 (1973).Â  While we found
  fundamental fairness was not violated by suspension after a one-year delay, we
  allowed that there might be circumstances under which it could be soundly held
  that the State had no right to suspend a driverâ€™s license after a lengthy delay. Id. at 411, 200 S.E.2d at 391.Â  We find in the instant case the
  extreme circumstances contemplated by Chavis.Â  Â Â 
While
  we do not intend to set forth a bright line rule, we find that imposition of a
  suspension after more than twelve years delay, where Respondent bears no fault
  for the delay, is manifestly a denial of fundamental fairness.[2]Â 
  Though neither dispositive nor directly applicable to the instant case, we note
  that Title 56 of the South Carolina Code, which addresses â€œMotor Vehicles,â€ is
  replete with ten-year limitations for purposes of sentence enhancement and
  keeping record of convictions. See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  56-1-746 (for purposes of determining a prior offense for sentence enhancement
  of alcohol-related offenses, only convictions within ten years of the date of
  the most recent violation are considered prior offenses); 56-1-1340 (violation
  convictions shall be entered in the records of the SCDMV for a period of ten
  years); 56-5-2940 (for sentence enhancement of convictions for operating motor
  vehicle under influence of alcohol or drugs, only those violations which
  occurred within ten years preceding date of last violation constitute prior
  violations); 56-5-1990 (in determining time of suspension of driverâ€™s license,
  only violations which occurred within ten years of the last violation shall
  constitute prior violations).Â  
CONCLUSION
We agree with the circuit court that under the unique
  circumstances of this case, the attempted suspension of Respondentâ€™s driverâ€™s license
  twelve years after conviction constitutes a denial of fundamental fairness.Â 
  The order enjoining suspension is therefore
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Having found the circuit courtâ€™s decision supported by its finding that
  Respondent was denied fundamental fairness, we do not address the remaining
  grounds. See Wilson v. Moseley, 327 S.C. 144, 147, 488
S.E.2d 862, 864 (1997). 
[2] It should be noted that neither Respondent nor SCDMV is at fault for the
  delay.Â  The unexplained delay in reporting the 1993 violation appears to be
solely attributable to the inaction of the State of Georgia.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Elizabeth M.
          McCullar and J.W. McCullar, Respondents,
        v.
        The Estate of
          Dr. William Cox Campbell and Palmetto Health Alliance d/b/a Palmetto Health
          Baptist, of whom the Estate of Dr. William Cox Campbell is the Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal from Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26589
  Heard December 2, 2008 - Filed January 26,
2009Â Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Kay
          G. Crowe and J. Todd Kincannon, both of Barnes, Alford, Stork & Johnson, of
          Columbia, for Petitioners.
        Kevin
          Hayne Sitnik, McGowan, Hood & Felder, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted
  certiorari to consider a Court of Appeals decision which reversed a circuit
  court order dismissing this medical malpractice suit brought against the estate
  of a deceased doctor (Estate) for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  McCullar
    v. Estate of Cox, Op. No. 2006-UP-332 (S.C. Ct. App. filed September 20,
  2006).Â  We reverse.
We
  agree with the Court of Appeals that there is no subject matter jurisdiction
  issue here, and thus both the Estate and the circuit court erred in relying on
  Rule 12(b)(1), SCRCP. Â In our opinion, however, the Court of Appeals erred in
  failing to exercise its discretion under Rule 220(c), SCACR, to affirm the
  circuit courtâ€™s dismissal on another ground appearing in the record.Â  
Subject
  matter jurisdiction is defined as â€œthe power of a court to hear and determine
  cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Dove
    v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 442 S.E.2d 598 (1994) (internal citation
  omitted).Â  Tort suits are within the circuit courtâ€™s jurisdiction.Â  Sabb v.
    South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 567 S.E.2d 231 (2002).Â  Here, on
  its face, this complaint alleges a tort and therefore is not subject to
  dismissal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.
The Court of
  Appeals cited cases holding the capacity of parties to sue or be sued is not a
  question of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  It is true that whether a party is a
  â€œreal party in interestâ€ is not a matter of subject matter jurisdiction,[1] nor is the issue of a partyâ€™s capacity to sue.[2]Â 
  What is at issue here, however, is not capacity, standing, or party in
  interest, but something much more fundamental: whether, at the time the suit
  was purportedly commenced, there existed a juridical entity known as â€œEstate of
  Dr. William Cox Campbell.â€Â  Since it is undisputed that Dr. Campbellâ€™s Estate
  was closed months before this action was allegedly commenced by the then pro
    se respondents, the answer is â€œno.â€
Â The
  general rule, cited by this Court in a suit brought by a nonexistent plaintiff,
  is:

  [I]f
    there is a lack of legal entity, the whole action failsâ€¦.If an action is
    brought in the name of that which under the lex fori has no legal
    entity, it is as if there was no plaintiff in the record and therefore no
    action before the Courtâ€¦Although an action brought in the name of that which
    has no legal entity is a nullity, an action in which a legally existing
      plaintiff has been misnamed is still a true action, to which the court can
    give full effect, subject only to defendantâ€™s right to object at the threshold
    for misnomerâ€¦.

Commercial & Savings
  Bank of Lake City v. Ward, 146 S.C.
  77, 143 S.E. 546 (1928) (Ward) (internal citation omitted) (emphasis in
  original); see also Blackwood v. Spartanburg Commandery No. 3,
    Knights Templar, 185 S.C. 56, 193 S.E. 195 (1937) overruled in part on
      other grounds Scovill v. Johnson, 190 S.C. 457, 3 S.E.2d 543 (1939,)
  citing the Ward rule with approval in a defendant misnomer case.
We reverse the
  decision of the Court of Appeals because an action brought against a
  nonexistent defendant is a nullity.Â  While the Estate sought unsuccessfully to characterize
  this fundamental defect as a Rule 12(b), SCRCP, issue, a fair reading of the
  record and the circuit courtâ€™s ruling is that the dismissal rests on the lack
  of a defendant.Â  The Estate raised this issue promptly,[3] the defect is fatal to Respondentsâ€™ suit,[4] and the action was properly ended by the circuit court.[5]Â 
  Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals reinstating this lawsuit is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1] Bardoon Props., NV v. Eidolon, 326 S.C. 166, 485 S.E.2d
371 (1997).
[2] Chet Adams Co. v. James F. Pedersen Co., 307 S.C. 33, 413 S.E.2d 827
(1992).
[3] The lawsuit was filed on December 21, 2004, and the motion to dismiss was filed
January 26, 2005.
[4] Ward, infra.
[5] We hesitate to say â€œdismissedâ€ as there was â€œno action before the Court. . .â€
to be dismissed. Ward, supra.
